summary: Set in 1941, an intellectual New York playwright Barton Fink (John Turturro) accepts an offer to write movie scripts in L.A. He finds himself with writer's block when required to do a B-movie script. His neighbor tries to help, but he continues to struggle as a bizarre sequence of events distracts him.

reviews.content: Amazing, twisted, dark and funny view of a writer's block with fantastic climate and great acting by John Turturro and the rest of the cast.
Uninteresting movie about a guy who hadn't written a screenplay before, not being very good at it. What point was being made here?

"Barton Fink" feels like a pure expression of unbridled imagination, probing the themes of writer's block, artistic frustration, and the alienation of the common working man in a bold fashion that melds everything together into a surreal web that stuns and mystifies us. Composite thematic elements leap out in unexpected places and just as quickly recede into the void before we're able to detect coherent meaning behind the quirky and mercurial story. This may frustrate viewers intent on making sense of what they are seeing, but it will impress those who appreciate writing that pulls out all of the stops and operates according to its own defiantly unorthodox rules. There is, in fact, a sense that the film is an exercise in rebellion against the established tenets of traditional narrative, yet it clearly springs from a whirlpool of engaging and relevant ideas. In short, "Barton Fink" is nothing if not wholly original, and is sure to prove a favorite among those who are drawn to the Coen brothers' most outrageously eccentric qualities.

Playwright Barton Fink (John Turturro), after receiving rave reviews for a recent Broadway success, accepts a lucrative offer to write screenplays for a Hollywood studio.  However, upon arrival, he finds himself with a case of writer's block, trapped in an overheated hotel room filled with mosquitos, with the only hope of manifesting his Hollywood dream being a picture of a young girl at the beach that hangs from his wall.  Directed by Joel Coen, it's a darkly humorous look at failed dreams.  The script, written by the Coen brothers, is filled with sharp dialogue, intriguing characters and interesting scenarios. Cinematographer Roger Deakins bathes each scene in a sepia-like light, effectively capturing the feel of the 1940s.  The only possible quibble one could have with the movie is the surreal scene involving the hotel fire at the end of the film, which feels a bit out of place, but it remains another finely etched film from the brothers.

Some funny comments from a few characters in this dream like world of a writer. Never a fan of the film industry genre and this started slow but then improved in the second half. Not sure if made much sense to me but it was ok. Early cameo from Steve Buscemi was noticeable but John Goodman owns the film.
Definitely will make you think.

Up there with the best of Coen brothers movies this boasts great performances all round, great sets and plenty of humour. The symbolism is sometimes a little obscure but it does not overwhelm the effect of the film as a whole or detract from the forward motion. Hard to characterise but a tour de force of its kind (if there is a kind). To some extent Joel Coen is a relative of Hitchcock but Bunuel is also there and the confection is subtly different. Stand out character playing from John Goodman.

My reasoning for watching this was very flimsy (Barton kind of looks like George S. Kaufman) but I'm certainly glad that I did. The performances from both Johns were excellent and they kept enough existential dread kindling that I paid attention to the entire movie instead of to my phone. I thought if I watched it closely enough I would "get it", but understanding everything was never the purpose here and I'm fine with that. When they brought in the two detectives to investigate a murder it started to seem like they were piling things on to intentionally obfuscate the genre and meaning of the movie, but they didn't do it in a way that seemed smarmy & egocentric like Lynch's Mulholland Drive did. I found Goodman to be firmly believable the entire way through his character arc and liked him a lot better here than I did in his movie from a couple years later, Born Yesterday.
One of the strangest movies you could see. Great cast.

Joel Coen's neo-noir, psychological drama, black comedy Barton Fink (1991) contains multitudes of ideas, styles, and entertainment. I found Barton Fink to be captivating in director Joel Coen's eerie atmosphere and haunting depiction of Hollywood. John Turturro is both pathetically sad as a narcissist scriptwriter as well as funnily naive and how out of his element he constantly is in every scene. You believe Barton Fink is losing his mind due to stress, anxieties, and deadlines. I must mention the unforgettable force of nature that is John Goodman. His hardy and hearty Charlie Meadows. Goodman delivers lines like Joel Coen is holding a gun to his head with a particularly brilliant display of fearsome dramatic acting in the finale.

Joel Coen's direction is dark and serious for The Coen Brothers, but he never loses focus on portraying old Hollywood. He grips you with a character study of a loser writer and all the emotionally broken people around Hollywood in similar situations. Judy Davis' frustrated and loveless Audrey Taylor is as tragic as John Mahoney's drunken writing legend W.P. Mayhew was wasting his writing talents within a bottle. Michael Lerner's screaming studio head Jack Lipnick is a riot as he desperately tries to pull a script out of Barton Fink with his raw charisma and supportive front. Jon Polito's Lou Breeze is dehumanized into being a loyal lackey to Lipnick with no dignity as a man or creative. Tony Shalhoub's producer Ben Geisler thinks he knows how to run things, but he's still subservient to Lipnick too. Even Steve Buscemi's content hotel concierge and bellboy Chet only lives to serve Hollywood types like Barton Fink.

Roger Deakins' cinematography captures the hopelessness creatives feel in movie making with touching close-up shots to striking dream sequences like wide shots like the flaming hotel hallway in Barton Fink's unreal finale. Barton Fink is as well shot as Miller's Crossing or Fargo in all honesty. Joel Coen and Ethan Coen's editing skills are as sharp as ever with a steady pacing that draws you into the mad world of moviemaking for 117 chilling minutes.

Joel and Ethan Coen's writing contains all manner of literary references and allusions to real writers or Hollywood figures. Barton Fink is fascinating as on one hand it's about the struggles of aspiring writers to overcome writer's block, find inspiration, and create something new and authentic, while being commercially successful in Hollywood's stifling corporate environment, wherein you are just another writer to them. Dennis Gassner's grimey production design shows how ugly and gross L.A. looks in his wretched set designs, while Carter Burwell's haunting score rises to the insanity of the filmmaking world with melodic shotgun blasts of sound.

On the other hand, Barton Fink is about how maddening writer's block and living in L.A. can be for young writers, especially in the brutally honest and cutthroat world of Hollywood. Thus, Barton Fink accomplishes the drama of showing how egotistical writers can be who are not speakers of their generation, nor voices of the common man and how crushing that realization can be for the author. In addition to the soul crushing world of Hollywood, Barton Fink parodies and satirizes how absurd writing for Hollywood is as Barton is ushered around from producer to studio head with no direction or real creative support. 

So, Barton Fink ends up hilariously satirizing both writers and studio figures in serious critiques of how toxic this environment is for creatives, while remaining a downright delightful black comedy of Hollywood's absurdities.

In true Coen Brothers fashion, we get a film with fantastic characters and a strange, sometimes bizarre, plot — we also get John Goodman, John Turturro, and Steve Buscemi. Barton Fink follows Barton Fink (Turturro), an NYC playwright who takes a job in L.A. to write (lucrative) B-Movie scripts. When Barton arrives in L.A., it's as if he enters a new world, entirely. I'm a sucker for creepy, art-deco styled hotels — which are abundant in the city of angels — but it's more than just the lodging here that makes the city interesting. Every character Barton meets is fast-talking, charismatic, or just a little off, or a combination of two or three. In this area, I especially enjoyed Mr. Lipnick (Michael Lerner), Mr. Geiser (Tony Shalhoub), Detective Mastrionatti (Richard Portnow), Detective Deutsch (Christopher Murney), Goodman as Charlie and, although only in a few scenes, Buscemi as Chet. Early in the film, Barton passionately expels the virtues of "the common man" while continuing to cut off Charlie — a traveling insurance salesman, the epitome of the 1940s "common man" — from sharing "some stories". I think the film would've benefitted more from exploring this angle and its relevance to today's growing disdain for "coastal elites" who not only believe they know better than everyone else, but know better for everyone else. While I knew something was off with Charlie pretty early on, I didn't like the direction of the plot (not really a twist) or the ending. The ambiguous ending gives hard Hotel California "you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave" vibes, especially paired with Lipnick's perpetual contract (this is illegal btw, but I won't let my lawyer show) and the girl on the beach, but extended to all of Los Angeles. Barton Fink has fantastic camerawork and a very cool scene concerning the Bible. It also has one of my favorite lines in cinema: "Jesus, throw a rock in here and you'll hit [a writer]. And do me a favor, Fink, throw it hard." (As I writer, I'm allowed to say this.) I'd bet if you asked a cinephile to name favorite Coen Brothers' movies, Barton Fink wouldn't even make the top 5–7, but it's a wonderful film only a solid ending away from cracking the (90)s.
Movie Rating:   7/10

John Turturro has had the strangest career. He has substantial roles in iconic films that established cinema giants like Spike Lee and the Coen Brothers, but cut to 20 years later he's mostly known for playing the most annoying character in film history in Michael Bay's Transformers movies (and probably cashed his biggest paycheck from those, as well). He and John Goodman are polar opposites in terms of career progression as character actors. But Barton Fink has got to be his career defining performance: a morbidly comic search for meaning, artistic expression, romantic satisfaction, and security that is jam-packed full of allegory and symbolism that functions largely due to the manic nervousness that Turturro brings to the character. It's almost a shame that he has to share the screen with Goodman, who is often completely absorbing and fantastic, taking attention away from the lead's contributions at times (not that removing Goodman from the film would actually be a good idea). The carciatures of the Hollywood stereotypes, from the studio executive with a flair for fast-talking and flash, to the laconic, Bogart-esque cops full of anachronistic quips, the film operates as a wonderful criticism of the peculirites of Hollywood, which made it a shoe-in for critical uccess that it still enjoys. The final half-hour, with its surreal imagery and wide range of interpretations, is entirely unexpected and wonderful. Expanding the Coenverse, maybe this provides a bit of background as to where Walter Sobchak sources his ready-made supply of body parts. (4.5/5)

Coupled with a uniquely unsettling ambiance and the signature eccentric wit you come to expect from a Coen Brothers film, Barton Fink takes its stellar cast and forms a haunting, open-ended story that demands multiple viewings to truly grasp it's symbolism.  Signature stylings of the Coen Bros. permeate throughout, yet the hotel setting is foreign from anything else in their catalog, and is Barton Fink's most distinct aspect.

The best part of this film is Baton's multiple encounters with W.P. (a drunk) and his wife Audrey, but especially Audrey and her dead body which is where we see a huge shift in the plot. W.P. is the writer Barton doesn't want to become, but that can be easily contradicted because W.P. doesn't listen due to his drunk behavior and Barton doesn't listen due to the intoxication of his own thoughts and this gets Barton into lots of conflicting trouble.

The film, Barton Fink follows around a New York play writer and creator named Barton Fink. After one of his new plays debut he is offered a contract to write movies at Capital Pictures in Los Angeles. However, when he is trying to write his script based off his assignment, he suffers writer's block and no matter what he tries to do in his hotel room, he can't write. During this period at the hotel, we are introduced to Fink's neighbor named Charlie. Charlie sees that Barton has writer's block and does whatever he can to help Barton. From teaching him wrestling to giving him life advice, Charlie becomes a friend to Barton. After meeting his writing idol and his secretary, Barton goes to them for any work-related need but still continues to struggle putting his story together. After a very strange turn of events, Barton has to deal with inner challenges as he tries to write the perfect script to be used in the pictures. 

     My favorite scene from the movie begins at 1:39:27 when two detectives are looking throughout the hotel and interrogating Barton to find Charlie, and Charlie appears from the elevator and a chase scene in a way begins. The reason why this is my favorite scene from the movie is because of how it reminds me of my favorite scene from Miller's Crossing. My favorite scene from Miller's Crossing is when Leo single-handedly took down two members of Caspar's gang. This scene satirizes one of the best parts of Leo's scene which was the fire, however it is used in different ways. In Miller's Crossing, the fire is used as a sign for Leo to know that something is wrong versus in Barton Fink, the fire is used as a sign of magical realism. The fire in the background when Charlie starts charging the detectives with the gun and it's even more well used because as Charlie gets more intense and angry the fire gets larger and grows rapidly. As Charlie kills both detectives not only as a way to protect himself, but I think he risks turning himself in for Barton, which is why I enjoy this scene more. This hidden meaning that Charlie comes back to kill the detectives not only for himself but to save the reputation of Barton Fink, because any association between the two of them could be the end of Barton's career. This also shows how much Barton means to Charlie because despite the fact that Barton never truly listens to Charlie, those interactions meant a lot to him and he was ready to do anything for his friend, which is why this scene is both powerful and my favorite, because you don't see a relationship like this anymore in 2020 or in movies. 

	I would give this movie a 3 out of 5 overall. The reason I would give this movie a 3 star rating because there were multiple scenes that I enjoyed a lot and had lots of deep hidden meanings that were powerful, but overall the plot line was very confusing. Like I said, there were some powerful hidden meanings, like no matter who you are in life or what you do, there will always be someone there for you, or it brings up the daunting paradox, that in your dream career, there are going to be times when you fail. Like I said before when talking about my favorite scene, when Charlie took on those two detectives or when Charlie and Barton were debating on what to do with the dead body of Audrey and what their story on what happened to her should be. Besides these two scenes there were a lot of confusing plot points, such as the cut to Barton celebrating and dancing happily at the USO Party. The reason why it was so confusing because it was a quick cut from a shot of Barton using the tears and death of his new lover to write his script for his movie. What makes it so confusing is that we the audience have no idea how'd he got invited to that party and why he is so happy after a death so close to him. I know most people who've gotten big projects completed shortly after a death, but they were still completely upset. The other main confusing scene, is why did Barton go to the beach for the final scene of the movie? We never saw Barton go to the beach or talk about going to the beach, the only beach related thing we the audience see is the postcard in his hotel room and the transition of the waves crashing on a rock on the beach. So to me it was really confusing, and unlike the first three films of the Coen Brothers, in which their hidden meanings were a little more clear and they didn't have any mystery scenes that were out of nowhere. The fact that they put these in just blurred the theme of the film and the entire plot of the film because if you end on a scene with no previous context the audience, including myself, are left to wonder, what just happened, in a confusing way. And in my opinion, the only time to say what just happened is after an epic action movie where it had a major plot twist, not a confusing ending, which is why I would give this movie a 3 out of 5.

Barton Fink remains a masterpiece as far as filmmaking & narrative conventions go. Just as entertaining and unmistakably crafted with ambitions not just far higher than what could have been, "good enough," for mainstream audiences or Studio executives...but also with the signature Coen Bros. feeling in every moment of every scene, every line of dialogue and the sets used to Kubrickian levels of perfection. 
  
No character has a small part, no extras are considered extras - as we've seen over the past few decades, the Coen Brothers ALWAYS make damn sure to pay just as much attention to detail (again just as Kubrick made The Shining the best horror film ever made by making such elaborate sets that had to be as close to the real fictional Overlook setting in the story). This is how their films hook you in with a sense of unique immersion, where we all feel personally served a special production that caters to our own idiosyncrasies. They do this by writing endless variations of eccentric main characters that we love to watch without ever stopping to wonder if we should be rooting for them, hoping they aren't kept from getting what their seek in whatever twisted yet morbidly accurate representation of the real world & our own societies they spiral around in throughout the whole film, usually running in place more often than not. 
   
John Ford was amazing. Billy Wilder is one of the best directors ever. Period. But even those legendary filmmakers could never make movies that satisfy the audience completely in the first hour without even advancing the plot beyond the first act, and then using the second hour to treat you to a number cleverly sharp turns to disorient you, all before high tailing it to the credits in a comedy of errors - quite literally - where the stakes are always shuffling around for every face still on screen. Some get presented as the unlikely hero for an hour, but then they get killed with a hammer off screen in the final 30 seconds and we only hear that's what happened to them through a lighting fast, hysterically delivered exposition between characters we likely have no connection to at all until that moment. (Burn After Reading.) 
  
Life is absurd. So their movies don't just operate with absurd stories. They play it honest and true to reality. The characters always seem like cartoon personalities, quirky for comedic purposes, and then suddenly one of them says something they shouldn't have & a mob boss orders the protagonist to execute the guy who is also a friend of the protagonist, resulting in a sharp turn from quirky comic relief B role performance to suddenly the most gut wrenching, heart pounding scene in their entire filmography, as Tuturro's big mouthed chatterbox uses around all five minutes of a single tracking shot to talk his way out of being hit by this mob enforcer who, again, is a guy he's always known and has no personal issues with. These all amount to cinematic masterpieces as isolated scenes in their body of work but also serve as small examples to prove that every scene in each of their films is loaded with significance, as well as being told in different ways that you've likely never seen done before until now. 
  
Barton Fink is just as insane as the Big Lebowski, but the former has very believably serious stakes for the central character who wants to prove himself a writer by moving to Hollywood after succeeding on Broadway already. Lebowski is literally about a man child stoner who likes to go bowling, and one day some people think he's another guy but the same last name creates confusion - so for a few hours we watch Jeff Bridges & John Goodman go vigilante in LA to get justice after some henchmen urinated on the wrong Lebowski's (Bridges) area rug in a modest low income housing apartment...you see how these are weird in different ways, and neither would sound amazing if you hadn't seen trailers or known who the Coens were etc. But I found out I DID care enough to watch Jeff Bridges bowl, drink, take some drugs, cremate his bowling buddy who never shut the fuck up, and then there's Tara Reid's offer to blow him for cash, a butler played by a late great Hollywood megastar of an actor, fight some European nihilists who emphatically remind everyone they care about nozing!!! They eat in n out burger, Goodman draws his old Desert Storm service pistol on a registered sex offender/pedophile IN A BOWLING ALLEY, (but not because the guy is a sex offender; he's upset they scheduling of their tournament doesn't respect his recently adopted Jewish traditions that his ex wife supposedly once cared about...?).

Before watching this film, my greatest fear was running out of Nutella; now, it's writer's block. And that's really what Barton Fink is about, a writer who can't figure out his story. Just the fact that this seemingly small problem is what this epic film centers around is mind blowing in and of itself. You think you know what's going on when you really don't, your mind wanders off and creates these complex hypotheticals. As the story unfolds, you start crossing off your long list of guesses until you are left clueless for about 2 minutes, then it suddenly clicks.

If I were to describe this film with one word it would be eerie. From the hotel staff to the tearing wall paper to Charlie's weird patterns of speech, the movie is just plain eerie; and this is what makes it so captivating. Everytime Barton struggles to start writing his opening words, you feel as if there is a heavy weight attached to your heart and it's you who can't put ink to paper. The film starts by making you feel uncomfortable at first, then clueless, and finally leaves you astonished.

Turturro and Goodman are as compatible of a pair as the Coen brothers; it really is these two pairings that carry the film.

Barton Fink is a unique and highly unpredictable film about a successful playwright who moves to Hollywood to begin writing screenplays and spends weeks suffering in his own private hell: writer's block. Barton checks into a hotel for a little privacy, and finds that he is frequently distracted by flies buzzing around his room, the constant peeling wallpaper, and most importantly: an extremely loud neighbour who can't seem to leave him alone. This is one of the Coen Brothers' more underrated films that sadly doesn't get talked about enough, and without spoiling anything, this film goes to some dark places in very unexpected ways with multiple ways to interpret the events that take place. The film stars Coen regulars such as John Turturro, John Goodman, and Steve Buscemi; with Turturro and Goodman giving stellar performances as Barton and the neighbour respectively. Their interactions begin innocent-enough; Barton fascinated by his blue-collar tales of being a traveling insurance salesman, but things take a sharp turn when we realize that Goodman's character is not who he says he is. This film is filled to the brim with visual and metaphorical symbolism, with an ending that still divides critics as to the true meaning. It's very difficult to discuss this film without spoiling the experience, so I will simply end by recommending this film highly for Coen Brothers completionists and for fans of the principle actors' work!

I am at a loss for words. I am a huge Coen Brothers fan, and I've seen their work gets twisty and crazy. This one is certainly no exception. I fell in love with the first two acts, because I felt to in touch with Barton and his struggle. Tuturro played Barton in such a human way. John Goodman was the epitome of a big bear; you want to give him a big hug, but also feel that he could attack at any moment. Once that third act hit, holy moly I was stumped. This film is certainly an acquired taste. It's smart, satirical, twisted, and intelligent. An unsettling think-piece, if you will. And that's not always for everyone. I managed to hold on for dear life, but can you?

Non è stato facile cercare di capire questo strano ed enigmatico film, con un finale spiazzante aperto a molte interpretazioni. Una cosa è certa, questo è cinema di altissimo livello, che pochi registi riescono a raggiungere. L'assurdità, l'ironia e la semplice perfetta esecuzione di alcune scene resteranno impresse nella mia memoria a lungo, vista l'intensità della recitazione e il velato moralismo che ne fa da sfondo. In particolare si percepisce una leggera critica verso Holliwood, o verso ciò che è reale e ciò che è fittizio. L'alternanza dei due aspetti descrive alla perfezione il blocco che lo scrittore protagonista vive in prima persona, riuscendo a creare un finale tanto affascinante quanto difficile da interpretare. Non sempre la mancanza di spiegazioni funziona, ma in questo caso rende il tutto ancora più misterioso e quasi surreale, un mix di emozioni che raramente si prova guardando un film.

Cohen brothers films tend sometimes to dwell on evil a bit much. This is not necessarily a bad thing. It can make for great story-telling. However, for truly great story-telling, there needs to be a corresponding redemption - so that even if good doesn't overcome evil, it at least stands firm as a witness, as light shining in the darkness. Not so in this film, where we have essentially evil characters beating up innocent bystanders. Therefore, despite the films merits, it falls short with respect to the great story-telling theme. On the bright side, the brothers have done a brilliant job at portraying evil - sometimes psychotic - people and the situations that they bring about.
No words to describe the total outcome but suffice to say, a total movie in full form. Beautiful... simple as that !

Damn. This certainly ranks up their with the Coen brothers' best and that's saying something, as they've made some of the best films of the last 20 years. With Barton Fink, the Coens have crafted a brilliant tragi-comedy about neuroses and creativity. In fact, it almost completely eviscerates Hollywood and the Hollywood system. In Fink's Hollywood, talented writers are taken in, chewed up, and spit out until they resemble very little of what made them good in the first place. It's also incredibly allegorical, referencing a number of biblical people and themes. Like most Coen movies, the writing is superb, with even the side players getting fleshed out. The Coens know how to create an entire world for their characters to play off of. The movie is certainly a lot to unpack and I don't think the Coens would have it any other way. This is a movie that would buckle under the guidance of almost any other director(s).

There are no other words to else describe the performances but to agree that they're genuinely terrific while following the Coen Brothers' sense of humor towards the intellectual empathy and twisted cryptic at a minimum. Out of the movies I've watched from the brotherly duo, including the majority of post-release, "Barton Fink" is the most inviting and most enjoyable yet. (B+)

Barton Fink is a beautifully shot film with some really stunning audio and visual moments that convey such a palpable sensation you almost feel like you are inside the movie with the characters. Also, when it holds to the story of a Broadway/Hollywood writer who believes he can understand the common man but actually refuses to listen, I am completely on board for the that movie. Sadly, it doesn't hold to that simple story. It is overloaded with symbolic gobbledygook that makes this movie nearly intolerable for me. I don't like when I have to do homework and analyze a film in order to fathom the writers' intentions, in fact I hate it. Some slight symbolism that might add some depth to the story when you look more closely is a fine thing to insert into a film, and it might even make it a more intelligent movie which I would appreciate. However Barton Fink wanders into a strange fantastical dimension where the laws of physics stop applying and people start saying things that make no sense, and suddenly I'm sitting there saying "What in the world is happening right now?!" It also kind of felt like the film was written and created just to appeal to the Hollywood artsy-fartsy crowd. It was so loaded with "inside jokes" that I could see other creative types just lapping it up but it sails right over my head. I didn't hate Barton Fink because, despite the rampant symbolic mumbo-jumbo, it did have a coherent story that I found entertaining at times. I can see this being a favorite film for some, it just isn't a film made for someone like me.

Review In A Nutshell:

There is something about films exploring about the passions of an artist, placing in situations that would challenge them and hopefully show their true potential. Barton Fink achieves similarly to what David Lynch has brought for Mulholland Drive; we are treated to a dedicated and brilliant artist to a world that is first unknown to them, and as their stay in sunny Los Angeles lengthens, they start to see sides of not just the environment but also of themselves that was never shown before. In Barton Fink, directed by the Coen Brothers, it is much more tamed and focused as compared to Lynch's, but throughout it remains surreal and terrifying.

Hollywood has been attacked by many filmmakers, as the heart of artistic destruction. They say this is the place where it lures the hopeful minds of the outside world and once they entice you close enough; they would devour everything that you once stood for and eventually become an empty vessel to meet their corporate desires. What I just said is no doubt an exaggeration of the real thing, but it is nevertheless real; there is this sense of restriction when watching the product of a Hollywood film as compared to someone who produced it outside the major studios, as creative control is always present in regards to the latter. Barton Fink's journey is definitely an interesting one and the way the Coen brothers depict this man's internal struggle for wanting to create something profound but also to meet the demands of his employers is terrifyingly real, and it does so without resorting to melodrama, but instead uses a hint of dark humour to create the exaggerations in its plot. The scenes that sticks on my mind when recalling the film, are the ones that involve Barton sitting across from his employer as these moments are the ones that represent the show business so well; the feeling of manipulation and artificial sincerity is filled during these scenes and through that I was able to really engage with the film.

My core issue with the film is with the dire twist that pops up in the middle of the film, as though it drove the plot forward and elevated its pacing, I did however find it to be too exaggerated and at the moment thematically confusing. I wasn't able to pick on the intentions behind it and the complete change in perspective towards one of the characters in the film, did throw me off with the film's flow. It is far from being completely ridiculous or abysmal, as one can feel the Coen brothers trying to speak something intellectually penetrating but one does need all the pieces, which I was unable to completely grasp onto during the initial experience, in order to fully appreciate it.

John Turturro's performance in this film was the best I have seen from the actor, and has completely changed my view of him. I used to only connect his acting work with the low-brow films of the Transformers franchise and Don't Mess With The Zohan, but after seeing him in films like Miller's Crossing and Barton Fink, it shows that even some of the most sell-out or worst of actors in the mainstream Hollywood business have films that showed a sense of integrity towards their craft. John Goodman has yet to disappoint me in any films he has worked on, and my adoration for him could be traced back to the lesser-known animation films he has done like The Emperor's New Groove. Goodman brings that presence in the room, and I say not just in regards to his physical stature, there is also emotional depth to his performance that could be felt throughout the film. The Coen brothers does not create obvious shots that would shape its characters, a lot of the time the camera is quite distant, especially the scenes between Turturro and Goodman, and through those there is subtle tension growing and at times we don't notice it because we are concerned with the words being spoken to create understanding rather than on what we see.

Barton Fink on paper seems like a straight forward drama, but under the direction of the Coen brothers, it becomes much more; there is a sense of passion to its characters, subjects, and ideas, and told so in a way that is surreal and profound; pushing the boundaries of the audience's expectations. I hope the next film I see from the brothers would be as great as what I have just experienced.

Loved it! The first great virtue of this movie is that by and large it does not have a "side" that it takes. All the distinctive, and distinctively flawed, characters are shown in their stunning imperfection. Its second great virtue is that it breaks amazing new ground for Hollywood by having a major introvert as a main character. The third great virtue is that it plays said introvert off against John Goodman in his best role ever as a seemingly lovable extrovert.And then there are a bunch of surprises, some cool symbolism, and, in the end, some events that allow the smart, idealistic introverted Barton to open his eyes and see what the world of "ordinary people" actually looks like.

An exceptional movie capturing the writing process, a yearning for something true and beautiful, and the contrast between writing independently in New York and writing for the motion picture industry in LA. It's not just a thriller, not just an observational Hollywood piece. The Coens are, as always, notoriously brilliant for transcending any genre, going above and beyond it. Barton Fink is a highly likable character, which is one of the many things that makes this film work. Any person in the audience can relate with this film in some way: with the madcap lunacy going on around Barton, with the yearning to do something great, with the desire to be blissfully unencumbered and inspired when producing art. Well done, Coen brothers. Well done.

The Coen brothers are two of my all time favorite directors. Their films range from comedies, crime thrillers, to westerns. They are fantastic writers and directors. "Barton Fink'' is an older Coen brother film, and it's just as impressive as anything they've ever made. The film stars John Turturro, John Goodman, Judy Davis, Michael Lerner, Jon Polito, and Steve Buscemi.

Barton Fink (Turturro) is a writer living in New York City. He is a play write who has just received lots of praise for his new play. An offer comes to him to come down to Los Angelis to write for a film making company. While experiencing writers block, Fink receives a knock at his apartment door. Behind it stands his new neighbor, Charlie Meadows (Goodman), a salesman. The two of them hit it off pretty well. Fink is the upstate writer with lots of awards and praise, Charlie is the average every man who lives simply. As Barton struggles to write his script, Charlie keeps paying him visits. They sit and talk about their lives. Unknown to Barton is aÂ terrible shocking truth.

John Turturro and John Goodman are perfect in this film. The two of them have this chemistry that just lights you on fire. Their scenes together are priceless fun. That being said, the performances in this are all fantastic. The characters are quirky and very well written, as all Coen characters are. The film is wonderfully shot by Rodger Deakins. Each shot is inventive and looks good. The film is full to the brim of great clever humor, given to us by our leads. There's nothing I didn't like about this movie. It's perfect.

"Barton Fink'' is a bizarrely fantastic Coen brothers film. It's one of their best. The characters are great, the writing is phenomenal, the cinematography is sharp, the acting is superb, and it has an interesting ending. The film is driven by Goodman and Turturro's brilliant chemistry and performances, and also driven by masterful direction from Joel and Ethan Coen.

Another masterpiece by the Coen Brothers with some of the best acting ever seen in cinema, the careers of all who appeared in this film were launched by this gem.  A classic that you can't get enough of, one of the best written movies ever made.

A renowned New York playwright goes to California to write the screenplay for a wrestling movie. There, he experiences a frustrating writer's block and is exposed to a darker side of Hollywood. Barton Fink works on many levels - whether it is taken as a satirical piece on the artist's constant struggle to let taste and originality prevail over industrial demants or whether it is taken at a satirical look on the film industry. Nevertheless, its creative use of twisted imagery and unnerving atmosphere also makes this film quite possibly the darkest vision the Coens ever came up with. Yet, the screenplay also makes use of some quirky sense of humour that makes it delightful while it is also able to distinguish itself among the numerous other films dealing with the theme of the writer's block. Great on a visual standpoint too, while the acting - including a very troubled and twitchy Turturro in the leading role - is also superb.
A very interesting story with dark turns and strangely comedic dialog, make this almost a masterpiece.
A very funny and quirky movie, I wouldn't say it's the Coen brother's best work but still very good. The acting was wonderful and the writing was at the Ceon brother's best.

This is one of the strangest movies i have ever seen in my life, and that's exactly why i love it. Barton Finks strange tale of joining the hollywood system starts out like i expected, a writer who claims to understand "The common man" but really doesn't listen at all but to himself and john goodman is his apologetic neigbor whose fascinated by Barton's words. All the while fink is looking to his drunken idol for advice and being praised by the head executive of the studio while being constantly put down by his producer.

Then about an hour in everything goes crazy and you have question if this is the same movie anymore, but the message is more symbolic then in the first hour. It's strange and apparently filled with themes and messages i never even noticed. It's an interesting look at the Hollywood and just how hard it can be to find the spark to write. It's a darn good film.

That being said it is, as is parr for the Coen brothers, something really great and special.  Barton Fink goes off to write for the movies and it is certainly not what he signed up for.  You will not understand what's really going on. It you will sit there riveted to it as much if not more so than Barton is riveted to the bathing beauty on his wall.

A brilliant film with layers of subtext.

Often described as a story about writer's block, it's more accurately a story about someone who isn't who he thinks he is.  Barton thinks of himself as a champion of the common man, but when asked to write a simple genre film, he is stuck because he actually knows nothing about the people he champions.  Almost everyone else in the film isn't who they seem to be, mirroring Bart's predicament.  This is all wrapped in a fairly deft satire of Hollywood in the 40s.

Definitely one of the Coens' less immediate movies, but also I think one of their more personal ones. I found it stilted and boring at first, but it grew on my slowly but surely until I quite liked it by the end. It's one of the more measured and mature and fair writer's block movies I've seen. And as far as their unique magical realist tone goes, this might be their best grasp of it.

A dark allegorical tale of hells in various shapes: the hell of living in one's life shelled out (W.P.), the hell of living with a corpse of a man (Audrey), and the hells of common man and the tourists traveling across different cells of hell.  The obvious inspiration is Inferno, but that is just my opinion.

With some truly striking imagery camerawork from Roger Deakins, a characteristically bleak narrative from the Coens, and some thematically rich ideas all throughout, "Barton Fink" slides faultlessly across genres with surprising ease and grace.

What Joel and Ethan Coen provide to the film industry in Barton Fink is a simple story based on the writers block The Coen Brothers faced during production of Miller's Crossing. The script is clever, and the plot is very simple, so what is required to make it work is good direction, a creative film style and a talented cast.

Barton Fink is bereft of none of these things, and proves to be an Academy Award nominated artistic breakthrough for The Coen Brothers.
Written over the timespan of 3 weeks, Barton Fink features an insightful script which delves into the depth of characters faced with writers block, shame and the simple disrespect of being a human being. It conveys these messages by taking its basic plot and fulling it with in depth dynamics from a meaningful script which gives plenty of character insight and depth to the figures on screen, and it makes Barton Fink an excellent display of the human mind. 
And full of the stylistic direction that The Coen Brothers always manage to supply, Barton Fink is a simple artistic piece which benefits from their skills as filmmakers.
And bravado performances keep it alive.
As an embodiment of the writers block the directors were faced with whilst writing Miller's Crossing, John Tuturro gives an excellent lead performance as a deep and meaningful writer faced in a challenging world full of fears. He constantly has a facial expression that makes it look like he is in serious thought and developing a great idea for his script, yet balancing it with a sense of uncertainty. His embodiment of The Coen Brothers themselves is a powerful performance, one of his career's best.
But John Goodman completely steals the screen in Barton Fink. His portrayal of a psychologically tormented everyman pushed over the edge by society is so organic and ripe with John Goodman's talent for aggression and deep meaning in line delivery. His passion as an actor is on full display in Barton Fink, and it's wonderful to behold as some of his finest effort.
Michael Lerner was also good although needing more screen time, and John Mahoney supplied a genial presence and strong performance
Steve Buscemi was also good, and Jon Polito was talented as always.

So Barton Fink proves to be a well constructed and cleverly written piece which shows off the fact that even in the difficult situation of writers block, The Coen Brothers can craft an excellent film.
Barton Fink is filled with enough twists and turns to be entertaining.

Barton Fink is a great film directed by the Coen Brothers, and it tells a really compelling story based on a smartly, well written screenplay that only the Coen Brothers could write. Each of their films are unique in their own way and this is very much the case with this impressive movie. A talented Playwright goes to Hollywood to start work on his first screenplay, and he discovers that Hollywood is much harder than what he thought it was going to be. The portrayal of Barton Fink is immaculate in the hands of actor John Torturro, who has done some impressive work with the Coens since. With this film, he really displays the talent that he uses to great advantage, and you are simply captivated by his performance.  This is a superb drama film that is among their best piece of work. With a brilliant cast at their disposal, and a well written script, Barton Fink is a must watch for viewers that enjoy a compelling dramatic work. Barton Fink isn't a perfect film, but nonetheless it is a fine example of why the Coen Brothers are terrific filmmakers who can tell an engaging story. Barton Fink is a well crafted picture that showcases great talent on-screen and it is a film that stands out among the Coen Brothers strongest efforts. That is a strong statement, because each of their efforts are well executed, well thought out storylines and effective performances that really make their work stand out among other directors. I really enjoyed the film, and thought that the cast and story were quite wonderful, and it could have been better in some areas, but overall this is yet another solid piece of cinema from two directors who know how to spin a terrific yarn.

Barton Fink is truly a great film, and the Coen Brothers have yet again added another movie to my all time favorite list. There are so many interesting things to say about this film. Instead of saying all of them I'll focus specifically on the analysis I concocted so that I might not be a repetitive reviewer.

My opinion is that this film is essentially a Flannery O'Connor short story, set in California rather than the South. 95% (no that was not scientifically proven) of O'Connor's short stories are essentially the same thing, and this follows it to a tee. To start, in O'Connor's work there must be always a intellectual, self righteous person that possesses enormous amounts of prejudice (Barton). This pompous character comes into contact someway with another character (Goodman) who appears to be more simple than our MC (main character). The MC mistreats this other character. The MC then discovers the truth about this other character, and is shocked to find out how wrong they were. In doing this, Character #2 offers redemption to the MC. This was most clearly shown in "Good Country People" and most famously "A Good Man is Hard to Find." Also, as previously pointed out the girl on the beach was influenced by "The Enduring Chill."

Brilliant storytelling, rife with complex symbolism that doesn't want to give you a neat package of explanations like other mind-benders do (e.g. Fight Club); not to say these movies are not smart in their own right, but what the Coen brothers do with Barton Fink far outstrips the merits of the Fight Clubs et al; it's like comparing the Black Keys to legends of classic rock: they're pretty darn good (especially compared to contemporaries!), but they ain't Hendrix or Zeppelin.
whoa, didn't see that one coming!
Another hugely favorable film from the Coen Brothers, showing their signature humor and dark creepy satire.

A man moves from New York to Hollywood hoping to make it as a film writer, Barton Fink as a whole is a satire to the notion of artistic creations. While writers in the story like Fink and Mayhew claims themselves to be artists and understanding of the struggles and glories of the everyday people, it is satisfying to watch how little they actually understand these concepts. With the paper thin walls of the hotel, it is perhaps not surprising for characters like Charlie to be enraged by their feigned sincerity, and for their abrupt and forced intrusion into their lives. Ultimately it is not this understanding that sells in the box office, but a much simpler method that could be achieved only by everyday people. What Barton Fink experienced was not a writer's block, but the inability to construct a simple story which his complex mind could not conjure. A beautiful premise behind a gorgeous film, but the film overall is really hard to fully apprehend as I am still left puzzled by several motifs and symbols.

Wie kommt nun Barton Fink" zu dieser Ehre? Nun gut, ich mag Filme über Schreiber und zur Abwechslung hat mich die Absurdität der Coens kaum gestört.

John Turturro ist Barton Fink. Barton ist ein erfolgreicher Stückeschreiber am Broadway der 30er Jahre, der nun einem Angebot eines Filmstudios nach Hollywood folgt, und dort erst einmal von einer Schreibblockade befallen wird.
Darüberhinaus scheint sein Hotelzimmer verrückt zu spielen, und sein Nachbar Charlie lenkt ihn ebenfalls ab.
Barton ist damit beauftragt worden ein Ringer-B-Movie für Wallace Beery zu verfassen obwohl er sich so gar nicht mit Ringen auskennt. In seiner Verzweiflung kapselt er sich immer mehr ab, anstatt in die Welt hinauszugehen und echte Erfahrungen zu sammeln - oder bloß den Geschichten Charlies zur Inspiration zu lauschen. Er versucht eine Geschichte zu erdichten und ignoriert die bizarren und inspirierenden Vorkommnisse um ihn herum.

Natürlich darf auch ein Massenmörder und eine brutale Schießerei nicht fehlen, wobei die Gebrüder dieses Mal tatsächlich eine passende Allegorie zwischen der Hölle der Schreibblockade und den endlosen Gängen des Hotels die schließlich in Flammen aufgehen schaffen.

Die endlosen Weiten des Hotels lassen an Kubricks The Shining" erinnern. Ein Film der Barton Fink" auch thematisch zu inspirieren scheint. Ähnlich großartig wie bei Kubricks Meisterwerk arbeiten die Coens mit der Kamera und schaffen so eine Atmosphäre der Endlosigkeit und Einsamkeit zugleich.

John Turturro, langjähriger Wegbegleiter der Coens, ebenso wie Co-Star John Goodman, geben beide starke Performances, das Salz in der Suppe sind aber die kleineren Parts wie Tony Shalhoub als Produzent von Bartons Film und Michael Lerner als Studioboss (eine Rolle die ihm immerhin eine Oscar-Nominierung brachte).

Die Kritik am Studiosystem ist nicht neu, und für die Coen Brothers war der Film eine Übung zur Überwindung ihrer eigenen Schreibblockade während sie an Miller's Crossing" gearbeitet hatten. Das Ende ist mir persönlich etwas zu surreal, aber von den Coens darf man ohnehin keinen gewöhnlichen Film erwarten. Außerdem fehlte mir etwas der 30er spezifische Charme in der Ausstattung und den Kostümen.

Aber wie auch immer, man muss froh sein, dass einem auch seine Nemesis-Regisseure Hin und Wieder einen guten Film präsentieren.

Ambiguous, thought-provoking, and bizarre as only the Coens could make it to be, Barton Fink is a journey through the mind and the study of a  troubled soul whose creative ideas are wasted on an industry concerned only with power and public appeal. John Turturro plays the title character, a New York play-write who is invited to Hollywood to write for the movies while he is enjoying the success of his play. He takes the offer and checks in to a large, daunting hotel where he meets Charlie (John Goodman), an insurance salesman with whom Barton shares his ideas of the "common man." As soon as Barton settles down to write his first movie script, he becomes burdened with writer's block. The wrestling picture he is told to write for is all too simple and undeniably a B-movie, thus Barton is unable to find the words. Throughout the movie are capable, decisive characters who have the jobs they do simply because they know how to handle them well, like the film studio executive, who mostly decides who stays in the industry and who goes. The "technicalities" are irrelevant. Charlie is introduced as a warm and considerate man who visits Barton often to help him with writing and to tell him stories. he seems like a simple-minded man. But, as Barton learns by the end of the movie, he himself has no clearer an image of the "common man" than Charlie does. The actors do a fine job of playing the varied and odd characters of the movie, and the setting, which is is often a room with little decoration, gives a feeling of the dread of something very close and inescapable, which we learn is the mind itself. Due to the rather simplistic story but the vast and complex ideas one is left to ponder, the movie remains fascinating, both during and after viewing.
I actually found I liked it less on my second viewing but it is certainly a well-made, though slow-paced, story. The acting is also great.

Probably the closest the Coen Brothers have to an horror film, this deep, awkward and hard to categorize piece of film making is always impressive, even when it's doing so many different things at the same time. This could be simplisticly told as an exhagerated metaphor to a writer's block but there's just so much more going on, that it's always a pleasure to go back to this strange world and delve into it's intricacies some more. From the insinuations of the poor conditions offered to a screenwriter in Hollywood, to how those shady and exhuberant characters behave with their "businesses", to the dialogues, the cinematography, the dark humour, the performances, everything just works when it shouldn't. And that's the testimony to these brothers incredible talent to have a unique voice when many others contempt in saying what was already said before.

Barton Fink is still fresh and unique even after all these years.

This is a fantastic film.  Fabulous performances all around, the Coens' trademark humor.  And even if you don't enjoy the Coens' particularly brand of humor, the script is still top-notch without it.  At the same time this is a movie that is simply littered in detail.  It's a film that has been dissected throughout the years for what it alludes to, allegories, relationship to real life people, the way Hollywood worked back in the old days.  It's a film that's been dissected so many times that I'm not even going to bother going into it, because people have already done so and done so much better than I ever could.  I think the movie would still be enjoyable even if you didn't dig want to dig deeper.  But it is a movie that sort of sticks with you hours, even days, after you watch it.  I think the film is a mystery to be solved and that's part of the joy of watching it, at least to me.  Because the more you find out, the more unsettling the film is.  The Earle Hotel certainly has a very surreal quality to it and it certainly makes you question the reality of the events that take place there, because things start to get worse around the hotel with Barton's deteriorating mental state.  This deterioration is excellently showcased by John Turturro's performance, you can sense how he is truly losing his mind over this wrestling picture that should, as several people mention in the film, is just about following a simple formula.  A formula that Barton simply doesn't wish to follow as he wants to do something great.  I also enjoyed how the film looks at Hollywood and how Barton adjusts to this world that he despises and how he is simply disposable in their world.  As mentioned the film's performances are excellent.  I loved John Goodman's performance specifically because you never know what his motivations are.  He's a very likable guy when he needs to be, but you can tell that there was something off about him, but you can never truly figure him out and where's he coming from.  John Goodman did a fabulous job here.  John Turturro is also tremendous, the best thing he brings to the table is that he delivers his line with absolute conviction, it's like this character was an extension of his own personality.  As mentioned, John Turturro does a perfect job at displaying Barton's physical and mental collapse.  I almost hate to ignore the rest of the cast, but the cast is truly perfectly cast, not a weak link to be found. I definitely admire both John Turturro and John Goodman work and it was an excellent decision to cast them for this script. Coen Brothers are not new to period dramas but they have pushed a notch higher in giving attention to detail here. While the consistency with their trademark quirky characters in Goodman and Lerner are omnipresent here, what rubbed me good and bad was the abrupt meta finish of this movie.

Set in the 1930s, Barton Fink (John Turturro) is a budding stage writer who tasted his first success and gets immediately pulled by a Hollywood big shot Jack Lipnick (Michael Lerner). He is assigned to come up with an entertaining script about a wrestler while he is accommodated in a small time motel in Los Angeles. With the condition of his room deteriorating due to heat and a loud, intrusive neighbor Charlie Meadows (John Goodman), Barton hits a writer's block. With time running out, he befriends the secretary cum wife Audrey Taylor (Judy Davis) of a yesteryear's great writer W.P.Mayhew (John Mahoney). One day everything goes from bad to worse.

First commendation goes for the excellent set pieces, art direction and attention to detail for the period. The script does occasionally have its pace breakers featuring John Mahoney's thread, otherwise it is quite entertaining. John Goodman gives a terrific performance as an intrusive neighbor who knocks the door at the wrong time and couldn't stop blabbering about the trivialities. But Michael Lerner steals the show with his breathless lines and impeccable comic timing leaving you wanting for more. 
I am unsure if I am impressed or disappointed by the abrupt closing credits though it looks beautiful, but I am sure surprised knowing other works from the Coen Brothers. There are quite a few theories floating around the internet justifying the climax, none comes even remotely close to convince me. The turn of events with John Goodman's character comes off as expected but is a little underwhelming. Though the atmosphere is perfectly set for a thriller, it does not reach the levels set by standard so high for a Coen Brother's film

Watching the Cohen brothers' film Barton Fink is an experience that can best be described being the uncomfortable observer of a headache. The early 40s retro mood of the film is evoked by the sweltering heat, varnished wood, and peeling wall paper of Barton's decaying hotel room while he attempts to create a screenplay from the detritus of his surroundings. While others have described the film in terms of surrealism or being pregnant with symbolism, which might well be the intention of the film's creators, such artistic embellishments do not raise the stories content much above an illustration of a disturbed dream sequence in which the actors move mechanically through their parts as if they themselves were rehearsing the screenplay aloud. You feel no sympathy for any of the victims much the same as if a cartoon character were being killed. Don't get me wrong, this film is an artistic creation but it's just too much of the same thing which turns into prolonged scenery. The trapped feeling that you get is as if you stood too long in front of an interesting painting at the museum.

This is one of the Coen brothers unforgettable films... Or, at least I'll never forget about it. To dub this film as a comedy is complete and total missjustice (I think I giggled three times), it's a harrowing film to me, something that alienates the human spirit. The images are beautiful, and the score that Carter Burwell composed is brilliant. John Goodman's performance as Charlie should have earned him so many more awards, and all other performances were haunting as well. This film works as a dream, and the surreal aspects are so very Lynchian. Barton Fink is my favorite Coen brothers film, that's for damn sure!

The Coen Brothers' Barton Fink is certainly among their greatest work, and also the most suspense and most horrifying movie that satirize the whole Hollywood system in such gruesome, but realistic way. It's the story about the successful Jewish playwright Barton Fink (John Turturro) who after a successful play on Broadway have been offered a job in Hollywood, which he barely accepts. He then move to Los Angeles and stays at a hotel that is in bad shape, where the wallpaper is falling of. Nobody in the industry seems to care about him. The only one he can talk to is his next door neighbor, a  suicidal lawyer named Charlie Meadows (John Goodman) who actually is keeping back a big secret that might cost Barton's carrier and life, but I don't want to give away the movie.

Barton Fink is a strange film, in some degree surreal, specially when it comes to John Goodman's, whom we really don't where to put. There's also the always weird and creepy Steve Buscemi as Chet, the skinny and pale receptionist who certainly never seen the day of light, they all give this movie  the kind of creepy and alienatiet feeling. There's also a lot of Hollywood stereotypes, such as the overweight upper class movie producer Jack Lipnick who is mostly based on Louis B. Mayer. And there's W.P. Mayhew an author who Barton looks up to, but when he finally meats him, he meets an alcoholic and violent man who have been repressed by the Hollywood system.

I just love this film for it's alienated, and isolate state of mind from the rest of the world. It's a criticism toward Hollywood, as it was in the 40s and how it is today, because it certainly hasn't change. I will not give away the ending but I promise you it's worth waiting for, but I have to warn you, the film contains much symbolism, and there's some questions that don't are answered. Thumbs up.

This end result of two of the greatest filmmakers of all time getting writer's block during the attempts to write their previous movie (Miller's Crossing) is an enlightening, original experience and the first collaboration between the genius cinematographer Roger Deakins and the Brothers. However, give it a couple more viewings and the meanings start to reveal themselves, if not always entirely clear. In addition to all this, great performances from Turturro and Goodman help make this one of the best films the Coen Brothers have produced to this day.

Barton is a New York playwright trying to cash in on his new success in Hollywood. Heâ(TM)s a pretentious intellectual, passing off his inspiration in common-man stories when he looks down upon them just as much as he does for everyone else. But heâ(TM)s also nervous around in his new surroundings. Andâ¦ he canâ(TM)t write. Unfamiliar with the movies, with the wrestling setting of his first assignment or with anyone in town; Barton begins to sweat as- day by day- he accomplishes nothing. One night he calls a lady friend for help- and wakes up with her dead in his bed. From there, it getsâ¦ surreal.

A lot has already been written about the symbolism in this film. Itâ(TM)s a lot to wrap our head around. Christ, the Wikipedia write up alone is 26 pages and 11,000 words. Gone With The Wind 16/7,000. And if the middle act wasn't so dull, I'm sure I would love this film more. It is rather flawlessly directed. Each shot seems so purposefully constructed; whereas in other Coen Bros movies, you might see more of a character domination. Not only that, no supporting actor is ever wasted. From the cops to the novelist to the insurance salesman; I was fascinated with each. But we spend too much time watching Barton climb the walls in terror of his writer's block.

Maybe it's worth it to go through that in order to get to the payoff of what eventually becomes Fink's inspiration. And maybe the point is that the art that truly transcends the nature of man is only found in the pit of hell. Or maybe not. But don't stop paying attention.

"Barton Fink" lays in a space where noir sensibilities and metafiction collide. This is a film first and foremost about the creative process of writing a screenplay but it quickly deepens from there. The character of Barton Fink (an excellent John Turturro) is an anxiety ridden, isolated character adrift from home confronting the unknown. The hotel he is staying in acts as a sort of worm-hole between the reality of New York City and the fantasy of Hollywood (an obvious reference to David Lynch). The Coen Brothers's idea of Hollywood acts as both noirish an extremely Altman-esque. Robert Altman treated California as a surreal, dangerous, confusing, parallel universe and that is what the Coen's are doing here. Hollywood is transient, foreign and self referencing and so is "Barton Fink." Like "Blood Simple" before it, "Barton Fink" is about movies. The Coen Brothers's, among other things, are commenting on the sate of cinema during the time of the films release by combining preexisting cinematic troupes to create something that does not warrant categorization, only an analysis that folds back in onto itself.

"barton fink" is a brilliant dark comedy about a writer with writers block. john turturro gives a pitch perfect performance as the title character, a role that easily could have been played exaggeratedly neurotic. but turturro plays the character very subtly, and with that you can really feel that fink losing his mind. michael lerner, judy davis, tony shaloub, and of course john goodman are also steller in their respective roles. "barton fink" is my second favorite film by joel and ethan coen, behind only "the big lebowski". anyone who generally likes the style and humor of their films, will surely love it.

The Coen brothers are undeniably two of the greatest filmmakers of our time, and probably the best tandem. The number of brilliant films they've made is staggering, from Fargo, The Big Lebowski, Blood Simple, No Country for Old Men, to Miller's Crossing. At the same time, they have also made a number of films that are well crafted by not as engaging, especially in a narrative sense, I found Barton Fink to be one such film. Its intentionally ambiguous nature bothered me, we think there's profound symbolism and a deeper meaning, but at the end, what does it add up to? It's well written, well acted, and often funny, but at the end it's extremely hard to tell what to make of it, the impression it leaves is both mystifying and frustrating. Ultimately, I really appreciated its great execution and some of its themes, but was left less than satisfied by the Lynch-esque final act.

Set in 1941, it stars John Turturro in the title role as a young New York City playwright who is hired to write scripts for a movie studio in Hollywood, and John Goodman as Charlie, the insurance salesman who lives next door at the run-down Hotel Earle.
The Coens wrote the screenplay in three weeks while experiencing difficulty during the writing of another film, Miller's Crossing. Soon after Miller's Crossing was finished, the Coens began filming Barton Fink, which had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival in May 1991. In a rare sweep, Barton Fink won the Palme d'Or prize, as well as awards for Best Director and Best Actor (Turturro). The process of writing and the culture of entertainment production are two prominent themes of Barton Fink. The world of Hollywood is contrasted with that of Broadway, and the film analyzes superficial distinctions between high culture and low culture. Other themes in the film include fascism and World War II; slavery and conditions of labor in creative industries; and how intellectuals relate to "the common man". Because of its diverse elements, Barton Fink has defied efforts at genre classification. It has been variously referred to as a film noir, a horror film, a Künstlerroman, and a 'buddy' film.
The surrealistic, abandoned mood of the Hotel Earle was central to the development of the story, and careful deliberation went into its design. There is a sharp contrast between Fink's living quarters and the polished, pristine environs of Hollywood, especially the home of Fink's boss Jack Lipnick. On the wall of Fink's room there hangs a single picture of a woman at the beach; this captures Barton's attention, and the image reappears in the final scene of the film. Although the picture and other elements of the film (including a mysterious box given to Fink by Charlie) appear laden with symbolism, critics disagree over their possible meanings. The Coens have acknowledged some intentional symbolic elements while denying an attempt to communicate some holistic message.
The film contains allusions to many real-life people and events, most notably the writers Clifford Odets and William Faulkner. The characters of Barton Fink and W.P. Mayhew are widely seen as fictional representations of these men, but the Coens stress important differences. They have also admitted to parodying film magnates like Louis B. Mayer, but they note that Fink's agonizing tribulations in Hollywood are not meant to reflect their own experiences.
Barton Fink was influenced by several earlier works, including the films of Roman Polanski, particularly Repulsion (1965) and The Tenant (1976). Other movies that influenced Barton Fink are Stanley Kubrick's 1980 film The Shining and Sullivan's Travels (1941) by filmmaker Preston Sturges. The Coens' movie also contains a number of literary allusions, to works by William Shakespeare, John Keats and Flannery O'Connor. Several religious overtones also appear, including references to the Book of Daniel in the Old Testament, King Nebuchadnezzar and Bathsheba.Brilliant performances of Turturro and Goodman in a strange and surrealistic movie.Does everything really happened(like the neighbour and the murdered lover) or it's all in Barton's head?

CULT MOVIE MONTH 
REVIEW #:012
BARTON FINK [1991]: So far in this month long look at a lot of various Cult Movies, I yet again find myself back looking at the brilliant films by The Coen Brothers. Now a few months ago I did a review marathon about the films of the Coen's, which was of course "The Coen Brothers Review Week" and out of all of the seven films I looked at one was the Coen's 1990 gangster film MILLER'S CROSSING. Upon looking into that films back story I learned that the Coen's during the middle of writing that films screenplay suffered from a bout of writers block. To most Artists of any calibre any form of creative block can be the most dreaded thing that can happen to them. Even the fertile minds of the then young Coen's became subject to the horrors of Writers block and it's with that block the brothers stopped writing   MILLER'S CROSSING and wrote the cult classic 1991 film BARTON FINK.

As one of the lesser known Cult titles in the Coen's flimography BARTON FINK this year celebrates its 20th anniversary and 20 years on it holds up as one of the Coen's most surreal, artistically bold and most haunting films from the Coen's. BARTON FINK blends together elements of Film-Noir, comedy, melodrama, social commentary, horror & surreal movies in one disturbing and unclassifiable package. Despite the problem to classify what genre of film this is, it's just simple to call this a Coen Brothers Film because it inhabits a world of its own. And in this surreal nightmare the Coen's made what can easily be called one of the Coen's greatest films that ranks alongside the likes of NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN [2007], FARGO [1996], THE BIG LEBOWSKI [1998] & A SERIOUS MAN [2009]. So in the 12th review of my month long cult movie marathon the Coen's 1991 triple Palm D'Or winning masterpiece is today's Cult movie of choice.

THE PLOTLINE

Set in the eventful year of 1941 in the later part of November and early December prior to the Japanese Attack on Pearl Harbour. The story opens in New York City on Broadway were a young Left Wing Intellectual Playwright called Barton Fink (John Turturro) strikes the big time when his debut play is a critical success. After mingling with a bunch of New York Aristocrats in a fancy restaurant (which is what Barton despises), Barton's agent meets him in the Restaurant's Bar with some big news. The Agent informs Barton he has just landed him a deal with Hollywood Studio Capitol Pictures to write for them. Barton at first hates the Idea and despises what Hollywood stands for and would rather stay in NYC and create "the theatre of Common Man" (even though Hollywood bet him to the punch), no sooner dose the agent mentions how much Barton could be paid , Barton's views are muted out and he heads for Hollywood.

In Los Angeles, Barton checks into the eerie, vast, and empty Hotel Earle which in the lobby only seems to be inhabited by the Bell Boy Chet (Steve Buscemi) & the Elevator Operator. After settling into his room Barton meets with the head of Capitol Pictures Jack Lipnick (Michael Lerner) and his assistant. Lipnick a fast-talking movie mogul in the meeting with Barton talks to him about writing a B-Wrestling Picture for the studio (while totally mute Barton hardly says a word) and an outline is expected by the end of the week. Barton upon returning to  the Hotel Earle starts to write the screenplay but after barley one complete paragraph is beset by the sudden bout of writers block and finds himself distracted  by ever since minor sight or sound in the empty and quite hotel. Barton hears a faint sobbing coming from the next room and rings the front desk to complain. Moments later Barton hears a knock at the door which turns out to be his Neighbour Charlie Meadows (John Goodman) who invites himself into the room for a drink with Barton. During the chat with Charlie, Barton barley lets Charlie get a word in as soon as the fact Barton mentions he is a writer come up in the conversation. After Charlie leaves Barton's writers block increases which starts to evoke a sense of panic from Barton.

Upon talking to the Producer of the Picture who is not happy to be involved with the project tells Barton if he is having trouble with the story, talking to another writer is the best bet.  After meeting celebrated Novelist W.P Mayhew (John Mahoney) in a Restaurant's lavatory and asks about how to write wrestling pictures, W.P offers Barton to visit him at his Bungalow. Barton soon encounters the ugly truth about a person he idolises. W.P has become an alcoholic and is abusive towards his partner Audrey (Judy Davis). Barton starts to become emotionally involved with Audrey when he realises the deadline is fast approaching and seeks her help. After passing out next to her during sexual intercourse, Barton wakes up next to a dead Audrey.  With a possible murder on his hands, the true identity of his Buddy Charlie is reviled to him after a visit by the L.A.P.D and with the impending deadline while still suffering from writer's block, Barton's world starts to be consumed by a total surreal nightmare.

THE ACTING, SCRIPTING, DIRECTION, SOUND & CINEMA-PHOTOGRAPHY
 
To start with John Turturro was simply amazing as the ill-suffering Left Wing, Jewish Intellectual Playwright. Turturro won a Palm D'Or for the role and it's without a doubt one moving performance. With the performance by John Goodman oh my god was it amazing; Goodman has in some respect been in other non-Coen films typecast as a likable character actor. Here in this film the Coen's at first use that typical Goodman image to make the character of Charlie as a Likable person to offset the contradictory Fink in the first half of the film. When the pity of the suffering for Barton increases it comes as a shock to see Goodman's character is really (SPOLIERS) a stark raving madman called Munt in the closing 10 minutes of the film. Goodman is just terrifying in this role especially when he wants to show 'The True Nature of the Mind". The rest of the cast are brilliant in their roles thanks to either the well written and brilliant supporting characters by the Coen's or just due to their performances.

 The Coen's created a truly fascinating story after the narrative to MILLER'S CROSSING caused a bout of writers block for the brothers. BARTON FINK loosely blends the Coen's comedic style with nods towards to films like Roman Polanski's REPULSION [1965], Stanley Kubrick's THE SHINNING [1980] & Preston Sturges 1941 comedy classic SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS. With the Coen's quirky style it's safe to call the brothers as auteur filmmakers and BARTON FINK is one of the best films to come from the minds of the brothers. Combine with every sound being amplified to terrifying levels and each shot of the Hotel Earle reflecting a weird hybrid cross between the visual style of Film-Noir movies of the 1940's (which is appropriate  in this films case) and the empty shots of the Overlook Hotel in Kubrick's THE SHINNING. BARTON FINK is a truly great film that deserves a definite 90% from me, it's just that good.

I love the way Coens coax the audience to ponder about the intellect of the plot. Brilliant direction, magnificent cast. For a while I thought I was watching the predecessor of Big Lebowski with Donny, Quintana, Walter and Smokey hehe. The oration of common man just reflects the pseudo-communist image. The scripts like "Bart you dont understand. You are a tourist, you came here for a while. I lived here my whole life. This is my home. You come to my house and complain I disturb you". Then "Hail Hitler" and "Fink is a Jewish name. Isn't it?" These scripts unveil the theme and the skills of the Coen. Another masterpiece like Fargo, No Country for Old Men and Big Lebowski.

After watching it once more, I am ready to give Barton Fink a five star rating. This is truly a gem among classic films, and the Coen brothers' best to date.

Labeled as a satire, many would say that Barton Fink is a take on how the writer strives to become closer to what he writes about (this case being the common man) but never ends up quite grasping the concept. 

Don't get me wrong, I see that. After all, it is the plot synopsis of the whole movie. But underneath its clever facade is a deeper message, a darker message. And if you pay attention to all of the minute details, you might understand what Joel and Ethan are hinting at.

Barton Fink is wonderful, but only for a certain audience. There are those who will be bored and unimpressed by the atmosphere and the subtle manner in which the story and its messages are presented. This is not their kind of film.

This is our kind of film, fellow movie-lover. Enjoy it while it lasts.
