BARTON FINK is one of the most bizarre and unique films. It starts off as a satire on Hollywood but soon things get really, really werid ;) . It surely takes you by surprise - I will give it that. The production design is another highlight. The peeling wallpapers. The dark rooms. The typewriter. The old time elevator. The rundown hotel has the perfect atmosphere for this story. I can't imagine Barton writing his movie script anywhere else! The film itself is open to interpretation. Was it all in his head? You can look at the film in many ways but it surely deals with the block of creativity. When a writer or artist can't figure out how to get create his next masterwork. The film delves into the pressures and stress that come with it. Barton's main problem seems to be his inability to connect with his fellow human being. He's supposed to be writing a script about a wrestler but he knows nothing about wrestling. He can't understand another's pain or suffering. He is literally locked away from the world mentally and physically. I think the film throws us into his state of mind. All the madness and absurdity. Everything just comes together in the most nightmarish and surreal way. Its happening but it almost doesn't seem real. Like at any minute - Barton is going to wake up and we can take a sigh of relief. So, while I found the transition of the film from a quirky satire to a surreal psychodrama a little jarring - I felt like its exactly where the film should have gone. Overall, BARTON FINK is one of the most fascinating films of the 90's. View it atleast once.

"Barton Fink" lays in a space where noir sensibilities and metafiction collide. This is a film first and foremost about the creative process of writing a screenplay but it quickly deepens from there. The character of Barton Fink (an excellent John Turturro) is an anxiety ridden, isolated character adrift from home confronting the unknown. The hotel he is staying in acts as a sort of worm-hole between the reality of New York City and the fantasy of Hollywood (an obvious reference to David Lynch). The Coen Brothers's idea of Hollywood acts as both noirish an extremely Altman-esque. Robert Altman treated California as a surreal, dangerous, confusing, parallel universe and that is what the Coen's are doing here. Hollywood is transient, foreign and self referencing and so is "Barton Fink." Like "Blood Simple" before it, "Barton Fink" is about movies. The Coen Brothers's, among other things, are commenting on the sate of cinema during the time of the films release by combining preexisting cinematic troupes to create something that does not warrant categorization, only an analysis that folds back in onto itself.
Barton Fink, an earlier work of the Coens will leave most mesmerized by the fact that they could fit so much worth analyzing that they could probably teach an entire college course about it.

Barton Fink is the Coen's least commercial and most confusing film. The first half seems like a straight forward writer's block story. The second half is laced with enough of the surreal that you're forced to wonder if the whole movie is one long dream sequence. It's not. The Coen's are experimenting. Don't get hung up on the surreal scenes at the end. Movies aren't real and the Coen's made a film that throws these rules out the window. Here is my take:

The audience is introduced to Fink just as he begins to gain accolades for his "common man" play. Immediately, Hollywood execs court him to come out west. Against his better judgment, he agrees and sell his soul to Hollywood. Fink arrives to California and checks into Hotel Earle (or Hotel California) the place that will represent the mind of Charlie, a neighbor Fink befriends. Charlie personifies the average man that Barton Fink endears. Yet, Fink's own self-importance acts as a barrier between him and those he aspires to write for. Fink becomes trapped in a state of writers block, finding no inspiration for the subject of his new wrestling themed writing assignment. When the one woman who can help him with his writing dilemma ends up dead in his own bed, all hope is lost. That is until Charlie saves the day by removing the woman's body and later giving Barton a human head sized package to take care of while he's away on business. Soon, Barton Fink is writing again, the mysterious package conveniently at his typewriter's side. The script is his masterpiece. Unfortunately the studio doesn't agree and wont shoot it or any of his future stories. Barton Fink's thoughts are the property of Capital Pictures, and he becomes condemned as a writer no longer able to create anything meaningful. He is in his own private writer's hell.

While it's symbolism may be somewhat heavy-handed (especially when compared to the Coen Brother's previous movies), Barton Fink is very atmospheric (somewhat similar in mood and style to Insomnia) and terrifically acted, although I STILL have no idea what was going on during the ending!

Barton Fink is a film of astonishing complexity.  It is richly imbued with enough layers of subtexts, metaphor, meta-reference and symbolism to rival that of many novels.  The hotel is the most meticulously riddled with details; as Barton's base of operations for most of the movie, the great amount of time spent there greatly lends itself to interpretation and analysis.  The film is a descent into the kookiness of the artist's mind, delving further and further into surrealism and leaving us wondering just how much of the film actually transpired in the way it is shown to us.  The narrative arc modifies and backhandedly pays tribute to the many storied personalities of 1940s Hollywood, which ultimately attests to the power of the author to shape and modify a story using previously utilized narrative conventions, characters and events.   At some point in the movie, the fabula and sjuzet reach a crossroads and take off in separate directions which only further baffles and intrigues us as we wait to see what additional facet of narrative Hell (typically in the guise of the ironic coincidence) is unleashed on unwitting Barton.  The many complexities, playful transmogrification of various plot and historical elements make this film the Coen Brothers' most postmodern movie; that's saying something based on their track record of twisting generic conventions.  The actors all do a bang-up job staying true to their characters and embracing the lunacy around them.  Barton Fink is a film that can only be labeled bizarre; discrete in its familiarity and genius in its commentary on the essence of fiction and narrative.

Barton Fink is a Broadway playwright that has been offered a deal to go to Hollywood and begin writing movies.  He can't refuse the amount of money he is offered and instantly moves to Hollywood to begin his new job.  Once he arrives in Hollywood, he almost instantly experiences writer's block.  Barton seeks the aid of a local writer to break his writer's block while also receiving encouragement from his neighbor.

"Are you all right?"
"No.  I'm fine.  Thank you."

Joel and Ethan Coen, who worked on Fargo; O, Brother Where Art Though; True Grit; No Country for Old Men; Blood Simple; Raising Arizona; and The Big Lebowski, delivers Barton Fink.  The storyline for this picture is interesting, well paced, and unique.  The script is well written and the conclusion is brilliant.  The cast delivers solid performances and includes John Turturro, John Goodman, Judy Davis, Michael Lerner, and Steve Buscemi.

I've always thought the hotel in "The Shining" was at least as interesting as the film itself. Ditto for the hotel in "Barton Fink." But for a few souls scattered about, both hotels are empty. And an empty hotel--if one uses his imagination--is filled with fun, intrigue, and mystery. That's also a good description for this film. Fun, because it is laced with the black comedy that Coen Brothers aficionados are accustomed. Intrigue and mystery, because the filmmakers needed to do something to spice up the narrative, which isn't all that exciting when imagined by itself. What percentage of the mainstream do you think would have rushed out to see a film that was ostensibly about a writer, alone in his room, trying to overcome writer's block? We must enjoy being romanced by the mystery and intrigue because if we are looking for explanations and explicit meaning, we won't find it. And the Coens rarely hint at what they have in mind. They just manufacture these stylish films that provide fodder for discussion long after the house lights come up.

Barton Fink must be one of the most personal characters Coen Brothers ever created. Particularly because the due themselves are essentially writers themselves and though they have a magnificent hold on other aspects of Cinema as well, it's their writing that always stands out with characters they create and dialogues given to them. 

And it's a masterful character, Barton Fink, created with utmost passion.He talks passionately about common man & the beauty of the simple truths but as someone wise said "Truth is rarely simple & never pure", he dismisses everything connected to common man or let's say never cares to learn about them. In fact his inspiration comes from something as abstract as a painting. At first sight, it seems like intellectual arrogance but as you go on you realize it's more than that. It's about your mind creating an identity of it's own and while you may want to project some idealistic vision, it has it's own fascinations. That's where Barton Fink is very similar to Polanski's "The Tenant". The concept of detachment of mind as a separate entity itself is what both movies seem to work on.

There are events & characters as well that just seem to be the manifestations of Fink's own mind. W.P. Mayhew played by John Mahoney seems to be a futuristic version of Fink himself who has accepted the domination of mind over ideals and same goes with two detectives who bring with them the characteristic humor of Coen Brother films. One of the Coens' most precious, Fink is a cleverly written little film that betrays a little too much of what the creative team is indeed capable of.  John Turturro is charmingly under the gun and Goodman is lovable as his neighbor.

As dark as comedies get. John Turturro and John Goodman both turn in astounding performances. Fink creates an incredible atmosphere with the setting which quite literally starts coming apart at the seams as soon as Fink inhabits it. Fascinating flick.

Surreal story of early Hollywood. The debates of the writers does raise some interesting questions on the goal of films.  The visuals are great (complete with the creepy hotel that would challenge "The Shining" for places you wouldn't want to stay).  A lot of the characters in the film have basis on real people that were in Hollywood at the time (though they are composites and put into a fictious story).

At face value, this film is incredibly slow and completely pointless.  But from a literary standpoint, it's loaded with symbolism and cinematic metaphors.  And like the typical Coen film, there's always an unexpected death and an ending that leaves plenty of questions.

Great if you're a film critic, but very dull if you're looking to be entertained.  I was the latter.
After it all, this will leave you questioning, thinking, remembering the subtleties and small moments that gave a simple story so much weight. A

While still retaining those certain Coen-esque elements and featuring the excellent character creations of the brothers, Barton Fink has essentially no story line. It is well-produced and well-filmed, but performances of John Torturro and John Goodman are nil compared to some of their better works. Still an interesting film, but Barton Fink lacks substance, and its surprise ending, while surprisingly, is jarring and unsatisfying.

A finely constructed but utterly delirious tale centred around the internal world of Hollywood screenwriters in the 1940s. The ability of the Coens to establish a plausible basis for the existence of mad-cap characters in their films was never as much evident as it was here, John Goodman being the shining light and Michael Lerner being a close second. As screenwriters themselves, you know that they are very close to the subject matter but it is in their ability to twist the story around and make it sinisterly funny that they apparently triumph, however excruciating it is to watch at times.

A playwrite from New York goes to Hollywood and descends into hell(or ascends, because the elevator did go up). I think that's what happened...maybe. Watch it yourself and let me know what you think. Very David Lynch-ish. Me like.

A beautifully executed commentary on Hollywood and its destruction of art. Paradoxically its also a beautifully executed commentary on the arrogance of theater and how it regards itself as a better medium than the movies. When the playwright Fink sells his soul to L.A. the devil has a field day. I couldn't help thinking that the hotel was full of other talented writers in the same predicament. There's commentary on how movies attacked the popularity of the theater but there's also a suggestion that playwrights arrogantly view themselves as being better than screen writers. The ultimate message from the Coen brothers for me is that movies, as bad as they can be, can produce art as good as anything we see in other forms. Where is this ultimate message you ask? Why, the movie itself of course. This has great performances from everyone on screen. Judy Davis in particular is mesmerizing. Her character is a wonderful parody of an old Hollywood actress and Goodman and Turturro are as good as I've ever seen them in anything else. Its visually beautiful and expertly constructed. Its a movie that will remain in your memory for good. So much can be read from the final scene that you could hold a conference or write a thesis. For me the box contains Finks creativity. Does its belong to him? How can it when it is taken out and revealed to the world? I could be wrong. In any case a brilliant movie. One I want to watch again already.

The Coen brothers are renowned for their work and no wonder. This being one of their first critical acclaimed works, it was obivous they would become two of Hollywoods finest film makers. It took me awhile to understand what went on in this movie after it had finished. It leaves so much to be explained but this ends up being the beauty of it. When you finally figure it out its so rewarding. The Coen brothers have alot of fucked up stuff in their heads, lets just leave it at that. Its a smart movie.

Excellent performances, brilliant direction, this is dark, twisted evidence of the Coen brother's original vision, warped sense of humour and delicious intent. Excellent early treat from the brothers Cohen and a must for any fans.

I'm extremely fond of Barton Fink, although I freely admit it isn't one of the Coens' most accessible films, containing barely any sympathetic characters and taking a rather abstract turn in the narrative - from a gloriously written tale of an intellectual theatre writer seduced into the 40s Hollywood studio system to a surreal, hellish nightmare. The performances in this film are some of my favourites, Turturro as the brainy idealistic writer who drives himself up the wall with writers block, not helped by Lynchian hotel he chooses and a "noisy" common man neighbour, played with creepy sweaty charm by Goodman. The writing is also sharp, and the film feels like a very personal work, indeed it was conceived by the brothers to let off some steam when writing on Miller's Crossing slowed to a halt. It feels like there could be a lot of brainy metaphors going on by the end, with head-sized boxes, hellfire and paintings coming true but I think that would just be too Barton Fink in itself. Forget the brainy stuff and enjoy the nightmare ride.
definitely a good movie, but i think it'll take a while for me to understand what exactly it was trying to say at the end!

And so, Joel and Ethan Coen take on their most harrowing challenge yet: ...putting John Turturro in a lead role. I'm kidding, John Turturro is awesome, apparently as more than just a character actor, but I'm not entirely kidding when I say that we are dealing with a harrowing endeavor with this, "The Fly III: The Rise of the Mosquito"! I can't help but think a surrealist horror film of that nature when I see this film's poster, because the titular Barton Fink seems to be really freaked out by that mosquito, and looks so much like some kind of a combination between Jeff Goldbum as Seth Brundle, and Eraserhead, and... Woody Allen. I guess all New York Jew screenwriters look alike, and yes, I'm very, very well aware that Turturro is Italian, and therefore Catholic, but then again, New York Italians don't look that much different from New York Jews. Hey, he must have had the Coen brothers fooled, because Fink is by no means an Italian name, although it is pretty popular with - you guessed it - the Jews. Boy, when the Coens said that they "didn't do any research, actually, at all" for this film, they weren't kidding, yet here they are, deconstructing Broadway and Hollywood, just as they deconstructed Texas in "Blood Simple", and Arizona in "Raising Arizona"... probably because they even realize that their films are bland enough when they're not set in their hometown of Minnesota. Well, make no mistake, this film, as the Coens' first rewarding drama, by one heck of a long-shot, is a whole lot more exciting than Minnesota, to a certain extent, at least.

Something that I really appreciate about this film is its extensiveness as a character study, even in concept, and yet, I don't know if a narrative this intimate is layered enough to warrant a runtime of nearly two hours, dragged towards with overdrawn meditations on certain material and filler that all but stiffen pace, while leaving what layers there are to this drama to outstay their welcome. The film is driven by the titular Barton Fink's interactions with eccentric peers, and the more time it spends with one peer is time lost on another, thus, when focus shifts, it jars, resulting in some glaring focal inconsistencies that are almost, maybe even about as detrimental to a smooth sense of momentum as tonal inconsistencies. Now, there are more inconsistencies in focus than in tone, because it's not until more consequential conflicts come into play, a little past the hour mark, when tone takes a serious shift, but make no bones about it, when the humor chills down a bit for the sake of tension, the twist, no matter how gripping, is a touch too sharp, shaking dramatic momentum a bit, or at least reflecting an ambition for dramatic momentum. Although they had never been so inspired by this point, Joel and Ethan Coen, with this film, had not yet fully cleansed an almost awkward sense of ambition, and there are times in which they get too carried away with such ambition to get a comfortable grip on structure, which isn't to say that the generally tightly fulfilled ambition is the most relatively distancing aspect of this drama. The Coens' trademark directorial thoughtfulness, being backed by particularly intriguing subject matter, a particularly razor-sharp script, and particularly well-portrayed characters, is particularly effective, but considering the steadiness of this narrative, material lapses often, and when it does, I'm not going to lie, the film occasionally falls into dullness, and when it doesn't do that, it at least descends to a certain bland coldness which shakes the bite of the film's subjective value. Of course, it's not only the cold spells that shake substance, as it seems as though the drama tries a little too hard at times with its wit and subtle style, and when you combine these reflections of ambition with such reflections as hiccups in a movement to meet ambition with inspiration, the final product finds itself held back, but only shy of excellent. I don't know how far this somewhat minimalist film could have gone, but through the flaws of a project of only so much consequence are the strengths of an outstanding effort, the glimpses of which are plentiful enough to make a strong picture whose inspiration even touches art direction.

Exploring the high cultures of New York and Hollywood, in addition to some of the grime of the Los Angeles low culture, during 1941, this period piece has a potential for diversity to its settings that Robert C. Goldstein and Leslie McDonald go above and beyond with when it comes to fulfilling through art direction that distinguishes each set and costume with an immersive handsomeness that is augmented by the Coen brothers' first of many collaborations with the great Roger Deakins. Deakins' cinematography might not be stunning, but it is consistently sharp with its subtle lighting and coloration, with a visual style that is made all the more immersive by impeccable framing and sweeping camerawork, and defines the final product as, if nothing else, stylistically upstanding, which isn't to say that style solely defines the drama. While the story concept doesn't match the sharpness of its interpretation enough to craft an altogether excellent effort, this film's subject matter is not simply intriguing, but genuinely original, in its approach to intriguing themes on the artistic distinctions between stage and film, and the social and intellectual distinctions and pain between big-shots and simple men, while studying on the personal conflicts of a man in strange land that grow heavier and heavier as the land grows stranger and stranger, thus making for an interesting film idea that is done justice by plenty, but only truly brought to life by the Coen brothers' writers. As with any of the Coens' best films, this effort thrives on its being so incredibly well-written, and even if the interpretation of the script is not of equal quality, there's no seeing this film as good as it is without the biting satire that is distinctly colorful, yet not too over-the-top, thanks to a cleverness that is anchored by sparklingly snappy dialogue that needs to be heard in order to be believed, and helps in tightly defining colorful characters who are still best-defined by their portrayals. One might expect a drama this minimal to seriously limit acting material, but most everyone has his or her time to shine, whether it be the delightfully over-the-top Michael Lerner and John Mahoney as flawed Hollywood sensations, or the effective Judy Davis as a woman in love with a troubled artist, or the show-stealing John Goodman, whose chillingly intense dramatic twists break which reflect a certain instability to the Charlie Meadows character punctuate Goodman's classic charm at its most dynamite, especially when applied to equally dynamite chemistry with leading man John Turturro, who is the real treat of this picture, with a subdued charisma that makes the titular Barton Fink character effective as an avatar audience who is distinguished by his own right by remarkable layering that never lose passion, but gradually mold Fink as a man of vision and fear, both for his art and his life. As much as everyone justly praises Goodman, Turturro is a revelation, and if you see the film for no other reason, see it for him, but stay for the Coens' performance as directors, who admittedly make sticking around a bit of a challenge with their pacing issues, overstylization and overambition, but whose more subtle stylistic touches go a long way in coloring up the film, and whose more thoughtful touches are often given enough to work with to bite, whether it be with dramatic intrigue or tension that compel, often thoroughly. In a lot of ways, the film is so good, even excellent, and it's frustrating that natural and consequential shortcomings are recurring enough to hold the final product back from excellence, yet inspiration is never lost, entertaining and intriguing enough to make a strong drama.

When the job is done, some questionable structuring that drags and finds inconsistencies in focus and tone, joined by some dull, or at least coldly distancing dry spells in direction, betray a potential for excellence, but just barely, for there is enough inspiration to immersive art direction which captures the era impeccably, handsome cinematography which captures style dynamically, and original and intriguing subject matter which is brought to life by sparklingly clever writing, great acting - especially by show-stealer John Goodman and revelatory leading man John Turturro - and effective direction to make "Barton Fink" a generally biting satire, intriguing drama and overall engrossing first triumph for Joel and Ethan Coen.

3.25/5 - Strong

New York, 1941: Barton Fink, commediografo newyorkese reduce da un successo teatrale a Broadway grazie ad una pièce sulla "gente comune", viene chiamato a Hollywood da una major per lavorare alla sceneggiatura di un film sul wrestling. Arrivato a Los Angeles Barton prende una camera all'hotel Earl, un buio e polveroso albergo i cui unici "abitanti" visibili sono il concierge Chet, l'anziano addetto all'ascensore e Charlie Meadows, un bonario agente assicurativo e vicino di stanza di Barton, che subito instaura un buon rapporto con Fink. Barton, messosi al lavoro nella sua stanza con due finestre vista muro, tappezzeria scollata e un piccolo quadro con una ragazza che guarda una spiaggia, incappa nel "blocco dello scrittore" e per risolverlo si rivolge al romanziere/sceneggiatore J.P. Mayhew e alla sua segretaria/amante Audrey, colei che da tempo si occupa di scrivere le sceneggiature di Mayhew ormai alcolizzato e incapace di produrre. Al risveglio dopo una notte d'amore Barton trova al suo fianco il cadavere di Audrey e le sue urla richiamano il vicino Charlie che decide di aiutare Barton preoccupandosi di occultare il cadavere.

Charlie poi parte per New York lasciando a Barton un pacco e promettendo di fare visita ai suoi genitori, ma poco dopo all'hotel giungono due poliziotti che spiegano a Barton che Charlie in realtà è un pericoloso serial killer. Travolto dalla realtà Barton ritrova l'ispirazione e scrive rapidamente un soggetto, che però viene rifiutato dal produttore. Tornato all'albergo Barton ritrova i due poliziotti che vogliono arrestarlo ma in quel momento scoppia un incendio e ritorna Charlie che uccide i due poliziotti e, mentre Barton fugge, rimane nell'hotel in fiamme. Barton si ritrova sulla spiaggia, dove incontra una ragazza, del tutto uguale a quella raffigurata nel quadro della sua stanza.

Another masterpiece from the Coen brothers. A surreal, creepy, and darkly funny portrait of an artist who sells his soul in exchange for financial success and finds himself in Hell in the form of a dreary hotel with a fallen angel as his neighbor. I warn you that this film requires multiple views, but then again most great films do. This is an absolute classic thats loaded with great performances and symbolism, one of my all time favorites.

Again, the Coen Brothers succeed in delivering another surefire classic, complete with first-rate performances, an original and quality-over-quantity script, and ever present and always pleasing direction.

I appreciate this movie a great deal for its themes and style. Writing in 1940s Hollywood really did suck and I know this now thanks to Fink. I also admire all the symbolism, but I believe there was almost too much of it and for that the film gets lost in ambiguity. I can't focus on the present scene because I'm distracted with trying to decipher past ones. A truly surreal and postmodern picture that you have to be in a certain state of mind to watch. Also, the acting was really good.

Along with the recent A SERIOUS MAN, maybe the most arty and esoteric Coen Brothers film.  Very good film on the writing life that gets richer with multiple viewings--Barton Fink (Turturro) is a how-to on how NOT to be as a creative screenwriter:  unobservant, self-centered, and suprisingly uncreative when "the chips are down."   Also, some great satirical stabs at the old Hollywood studio system, and a funny potshot at William Faulkner with a terrific drunken performance by John Mahoney as a famous author who may not be writing the screenplays he's credited for.  "I'll show you the life of the mind!"

Surreal, dark, and wonderfully ambiguous, Barton Fink is an example of a movie that is all about themes and character. The plot is inconsequential. What is the movie about?...A little bit of everything. It comments on religion, morality, the writing process, the dynamics in Hollywood, ect. ect. 
It is, however, a little too ambiguous sometimes but that's perhaps because I'm so straightforward. I love the movie but it's difficult to glean any meaning from it.

What I love so much about a lot of the Coen Brothers' movies is that you're left thinking about what it all really meant in the end, long after the movie's over. So much is left open-ended that it really makes you wonder how much symbolism you can discover from watching this movie again. Like many of their movies don't expect to get a nice, clean, cookie-cutter, Hollywood ending, but the ending will really make you think much more than the regular stuff Hollywood spits out. What I liked was that many surprises happen in Barton Fink, that leave you guessing, suspending you on the edge of your seat, wondering how it's all gonna turn out in the end. Of course like all Coen-made movies, it has that subtle humor in it but I'd say this is a lot more drama and film noir than it is a comedy. Not like Lebowski or O Brother. Barton Fink is hilarious and almost perfect. It is one of the funniest movies I've ever seen. Every time I watch it, it only gets better. The whole movie is about a writer who writes a great play and is asked to write a movie. But the only problem is that it is a B-movie. The writer can't figure out how to do that. So he he tries too hard and write what he calls his best work. The whole movie is filled with metaphors and things that would show up later in the movie. One of my favorite is the picture. In Barton's hotel room where he resides, there is a photo of a woman sitting on a beach that inspires him to write. In the end of the movie he experiences that photo. There is a whole story that is really complicated and can't even explain. If I hadn't seen tis movie, then I wouldn't think so highly of John Turturro (Mainly because of Transformers). He does such a good job in this movie. Who else could play Barton Fink, he looks like a Barton. John Goodman does well also. I think John Turturro should have been nominated or won an Oscar for his performance. I mean Anthony Hopkins won for The Silence of the Lambs. Where he only appears in the movie for like 2 and a half minutes.The Coen brothers should have won Best Original Scrrenplay. This is an all around great movie. but that's what you get with an awesome script, a great cast and perfect visuals.

Like most Coen brothers efforts, this film defies description or categorization, and within those boundaries it comes across as impossible to comprehend.

There's no denying that the story is genuinely interesting, even if it doesn't advance quickly or completely, and as the eponymous writer's life spins out of control, the viewer's eyes are drawn more to the form of film itself than to the story. How much of what we see is fantasy is, again, impossible to understand, and the Coens would rather let you believe what you'd like rather than offer some form of elucidation.

Regardless of what you may think of the story, there's no doubting that everyone involved is in top form, particularly Turturro, who perhaps exemplifies the most clearly Coenesque protagonist of any of their films.

If nothing else, like many Coen brothers films, any and all expectations will drift away as you realize you have no idea what's going to happen next.
Barton Fink is a horror film, perhaps the scariest film from the Coen Brothers, as its genre conventions and surrealistic depictions of writers block make for an unsettling nightmare of the mind.
major brain exercise. the line between fantasy and reality is helluva blurred here. smart no doubt, and the two lead characters were great.  couldn't and didn't really like it though.

A gnarled Faustian riddle of a film with an astonishing wealth of subtext. Barton Fink is an absolutely fantastic character, host to some of the Coens' most insightful sociological observation, and John Turturro is 100% on board with the person they're trying to create. I love the delicious narcissism he projects when he purports interest in the "common man," but ultimately that interest is self-serving, a means to an end for his own intellectual fulfillment. When meeting a true paragon of the aesthetic he's trying to capture (John Goodman, who is excitingly awesome here), Fink is utterly unconcerned with his attempts to actually teach him or tell him stories of his life, gleaning only what he needs from their few conversations. It's a full-bodied, riveting characterization, and it's truly a shame that Turturro didn't pick up an Oscar nomination for his incisive work. (Michael Lerner getting a nomination for his one-volume-fits-all shoutfest, on the other hand, almost feels like a slap in the face.) 

The rest of the movie, a visually arresting cautionary tale about reconciling the "life of the mind" with Hollywood's pernicious capitalism, is almost too cruel to put into words. Along with their typical emotional abuse of their characters, the Coens here subject Barton Fink to an immense amount of mental duress; the challenge in watching this movie is that Fink kvetches so much about every little thing that goes wrong for him that it's difficult to truly empathize with him. Sure, we understand that he's not a very good person and there's really no incentive for getting behind him, but it's that perspective that makes the movie's view of haughty intellectualism that much more cogent. Plus, the last half hour of the movie is a complete mindfuck, if you're into that sort of thing (which I definitely am). It's sometimes a tricky balance depicting a character's dissolving mental state on film and keeping it representational versus presentational, but what we see in Barton Fink is assumed to be no less than the truth, and the Coens play it totally seriously, in their darkly humorous way. They've never really warped reality in any of their films as they have here - some of their characters may act completely beyond human comprehension, sure, but here we're invited along for a ride through Barton Fink's personal hell. And it is great.

Now I can see where A Serious Man came from. The story goes that the Coen Brothers penned this film while suffering writers block on Miller's Crossing. I totally believe that. Miller's Crossing contained a depth of plot that knows few equals in Hollywood, particularly as far as gangster films are concerned. 

So how do you treat a particularly bad case of block? By writing a film about writer's block where all of the worst possible things happen to a writer. This writer (John Turturro) just wrote a play that makes him the toast of New York, so he takes a contract in Hollywood writing films to help fund his true passionate subjects later. And then he gets stuck writing a B wrestling picture, when wrestling is the last thing he knows anything about. Even though he claims to write for the "common man", all of his speechifying and his complicated thoughts show how isolated he is. And boy does he pay the price!

*Spoilers*
Everybody he knows dies and his helpful neighbor, a wonderful John Goodman, turns into the personified wrath of the common man, a demonic figure followed by fire who shows Fink where he really went wrong. And on top of all that, the studio HATES his pretentious script and keeps him under contract while publishing nothing, effectively burying him and ending his career.

It reminds me of David Lynch's Eraserhead, written out of fear of becoming a father it takes the absolute worst thing that could happen to a new dad and projects it on screen. Barton Fink is the same way. What's the worst that could happen if Joel and Ethan can't finish the script? Well, everybody they know could die and their careers could be ruined forever. Cool!

Bizarre but highly entertaining tale from the Coen Brothers about a celebrated New York playwright, a champion of working-class drama, is lured to Hollywood to write the screenplay for a wrestling film starring Wallace Beery. After checking into the highly atmospheric and somewhat seedy Hotel Earle, Fink (a high-strung and twitchy Turturro) finds himself struggling with an epic case of writer's block as he befriends easygoing and gregarious insurance salesman Goodman. The film works best skewering old time Tinseltown archetypes as cartoonish exaggerations (astute viewers will recognize ersatz takes on William Faulkner and Jack L. Warner - Michael Lerner doing a great job as the latter), but is less successful toward the conclusion as Fink's world seemingly comes crashing down around his ears. At that point, symbolism takes over for satire and interpretations start to abound about the nature of Goodman's character and what he represents. Puzzling, but the whole production is mesmerizing.

This was incredible.Barton Fink was one of those movies that demanded repeated viewings to fully appreciate. It was for me anyways. It's a black comedy that changes into something quite sinister near the end. All the main characters are eccentric nut jobs that could only feel at home in a Coen Brothers movie. It's something your either love or loath as they are so incredibly messed up. The cast are all superb, Goodman is outstanding,the man's a genius,it's hard not to like Charlie when you first meet him,he's so infectious,it makes it all the sweeter when you find out his real identity. Turturro is also perfect as Barton,this must be one of his best roles to date. The Hotel itself is a character,with it's wet walls and slimly wall paper. It would feel completely desolated and deserted of life,if it wasn't for the shoes. About the half way mark and the feeling of the movie changes dramatically. It starts to feel like a horror movie,the once wet walls of the hotel are now dripping with fire as Barton's sanity is pushed to it's limit. This is such a cleaver movie,this was written when the brothers had writers block whilst penning Millers Crossing. That alone blows my mind,that something this good was created that way.

Another dark, funny, sick joke from the Coen brothers. This one has a similar basic structure to their recent A Serious Man: it's about a nice but unexceptional man struggling vainly to deal with a series of baffling circumstances. This time it's John Turturro as Barton Fink, an earnest young liberal playwright in the 1930s who gets hired by Hollywood to write a B-movie. He believes his writing can help the proletarian "common man," but is actually not all that interested in common men when he meets them. The supporting cast has some of the best character actors in the business: Steve Buscemi, Tony Shaloub, Judy Davis, and John Mahoney as a thinly disguised William Faulkner. Michael Lerner got an Oscar nomination for his hilarious supporting role as a blustery Hollywood producer who pretends to care about art but really is only concerned with the studio's bottom line. John Goodman also gets one of his best parts ever as Fink's suspiciously friendly neighbor. There are lots of great little touches, such as the multiple ways in which Fink's hotel is made to seem like Hell itself. There's the creepy sucking noise his door makes every time it is opened or closed, and the way the wallpaper keeps sweating and peeling. The movie goes along in a relatively conventional manner for a while before totally going off the rails and into crazy Coen territory in the last half-hour. The fact that this was only their fourth movie is impressive, and makes you wonder how these guys keep getting away with it.

A strange experience twisted around magnificent performances from John Turturo and John Goodman.  Begins as a quaint little period piece focused on the entertainingly unique and sympathetic title character played by Turturo.  However, after Fink moves in to a hole-in-the-wall hotel room to write a movie, the film becomes increasingly bizarre.  Not necessarily in a negative way.  Despite it's familiar setting and comically cliche secondary characters (played by a stellar support cast), it's a stunningly original work.  Fink's increased isolation results in a disconnect from reality in the film which eventually becomes total.  "Barton Fink" is mildly disturbing, certainly weird, sometimes humorous, and often interesting, yet it lacks any memorable emotional impact.

"Look upon me, I'll show you the life of the mind."

Barton Fink is my long lost Jewish cousin.  I've never felt as close to the character's struggle as when I tried to write a review for it.  But a few hours later, here it is.

What's impressive about this labyrinth of a film and the Coen Brothers (as if they're not impressive enough) is that it was written in a matter of three weeks during a spout of writer's block while working on Miller's Crossing.  For such a quick scribble, Barton Fink has more layers than a pyramid scheme, steeped in social, political, and existential allegory.

Fink, played by John Turturro, is a New York playwright on the rise, chosen by a Hollywood studio to pen a wrestling B-movie.  He takes up residence in a run-down hotel where he tries to work out his mental difficulties, no thanks to the imposition of his loud, mysterious neighbor, Charlie Meadows (played by John Goodman).

I could go on for days about the symbolisms displayed...The wallpaper peeling in the hotel room that represents Fink's mind, analogies offered by the very film Fink is working on, references to slavery as metaphors of the studio's ownership of Fink's creativity, along with other strong yet accurate accusations of the Hollywood machine (the studio head exclaims to Fink: "This is a wrestling picture, the audience wants to see action, adventure, wrestling. They don't want to see a guy wrestling with his own soul!") 

What I enjoyed about this film also were a couple moments where I thought to myself, "is it okay to laugh here?"  It's a think piece that defies the pigeonholing of genre placement, incorporating elements of noir, psycho-thriller, horror, and dark comedy.

There is a quick transition shot of the California coast toward the beginning of the film when Barton makes his move to Los Angeles that, for some reason - combined with a picture of that same beach hanging in Barton's hotel room - felt like a serene yet uneasy foreshadowing of a painful end.  A seemingly harmless 5-second glimpse of waves crashing into a large rock that I failed to shake throughout the film's duration.

With its many faces, Barton Fink opens itself up to varied impressions and analysis.  And with its complicated simplicity, this film offers a high replay value.  Discovering Coen gems I've missed, I feel a bit forced to tweak the order of my "Favorite Directors" list.

It's amusing to see something marvelous created out of the creation process for a more-concentrated piece of work that fell under the radar as a "sleeper" hit. The Coen Brothers drowned themselves in writers' block during the creative process of writing their mob piece 'Miller's Crossing', which in itself was a muse to make 'Barton Fink' happen a year later. 'Miller's Crossing', set in the 1930's Prohibition-era, was obvious more tedious in attention to detail, setting, camera work, lighting, costumes, and the consistency of creative mob-speak; 'Barton Fink', set only a decade later in the 1940's, was a much simpler route in production, as it was intent on limited setting mostly in a run-down hotel room, and far less characters, and far less of a puzzle of double-cross. Both films do, similarly, involve a noir-esque descent of the world on the protagonist of Atlas-proportions, but my opinion: 'Barton Fink' is the better film. It tells of our titular character - a 1940's idealistic playwright whose underground success of the stage leads to a financially-endowed opportunity to write for Hollywood producers. His Achilles' Heel is the fact that he was a Robert Bresson before Robert Bresson made films (nerd translation: Robert Bresson was a French pre-Nouvelle Vague film director whose prominent intent was to make films that strip away the sophistication and glamour of forced acting in order to document real life of the common man or woman in a fictional story - basically a study in realism). Barton's integrity is expected to wear thin once he enters Capital Films - a large production company who hires him to write a B-movie about wrestling. Hitting one brick wall after another, yet experiencing a chain of unusual and surreal events while exiled in his dark, crummy hotel room, Barton finds it increasingly difficult to sacrifice his literary integrity to come up with a wrestling story. In the meantime, he befriends his neighbor Charlie Meadows - played by an uproariously funny John Goodman. Charlie Meadows takes on the identity of what's considered the 'common man': a struggling insurance salesman living a moderate lifestyle. Also entering his life is W.P. Mayhew - played by a finely-acted John Maloney with a genuine Georgian tongue. W.P. Mayhew is almost like an idol to Barton's passion of entertainment writing, but soon finds out how much of a false life he's lived, by way of Mayhew owing his writing success to his secretary Audrey Taylor (played by a magnificent and seductive Judy Davis). By way of film noir, Audrey becomes something like a femme fatale and a passionate fantasy to Barton, and almost immediately, Barton's world spirals in hellish, downward descent. He begins to realize himself what it means to be a true "outsider" - an "outsider" to Hollywood as is incapable of sacrificing integrity for a piece of literary work, and an "outsider" to the "common man" he desires to portray in each story, since he isn't such the "common man" himself to fully relate to. In the end, he's just a "tourist with a typewriter". This one is actually the first film composed without the signature cinematography work of Barry Sonnenfield (their weapon of choice who almost single-handedly provided the Coen Brothers with their films' signature style and look with fast-acting character zoom-ins and wide-angle frame-scapes), but whoever replaced him behind the camera and lighting sure took note of the past films which shaped the Coens' career. The Coen Brothers have developed yet another perplexing artifice to destroy a protagonist - everything from 'Barton Fink', 'Miller's Crossing', 'The Big Lebowski', 'Burn After Reading' and even their most recent 'A Serious Man' - they all deal similar cards in giving one bold human being the ultimate run-around. This one ends with something of a brick wall, with plenty on the surreal side to ponder about. 'Barton Fink' is certainly one of the more sleeper successes of the Coens' career, and quite considerably one of their finest, most puzzlingly genius bodies of work - not to mention, perhaps their most passionately simplistic 116 minutes yet.

Movies with ambiguous endings stay with you forever. Think of the first time you saw Lost in Translation (what does he whisper in her ear!?) or pondering why the birds came in Hitchcock's The Birds, the briefcase in Pulp Fiction, Magnolia, Punch Drunk Love, Broken Flowers, Fight Club, No country for Old Men and even the Dark Knight all present endings and elements throughout that provide intense interpretations and lend themselves as prime subjects for Zoom-In analysis. However, one that presents itself as a highly metaphorical and highly ambiguous film is the Cohen Brother's 1991 film, Barton Fink. The first film to win all three major awards (Palme D'or, Best Director, and Best Actor) at the Cannes Film Festival. Also, it was unanimously chosen for the Palme D'or.

The entire film presents itself as a metaphor for heaven and hell. Barton Fink is played by John Tuturo (what ethnicity is this guy!? He plays everything) who is a critically acclaimed playwright who is hired to a contract in Hollywood to make the transition into film. He claims to write scripts for and about the "everyday man." After being offered to bunk up in a Hollywood suite, he insistently declines in order to stay in an average hotel called the Hotel Earle. When Chet (Steve Buscemi, the hotel clerk) first appears he comes out of a door on the floor after it takes him a long while to reach the top, like if he was ascending from the underworld. - The word "six" is said three times in the elevator. - Hotel Earle can be an anagram of the words Hell and Erato, the Greek Muze of lyric poetry.

Charlie (John Goodman) is Barton Fink's neighbor who Barton feels an attachment to. Most people concur that Charlie represents the devil. Instead, I think that Charlie represents the repressed rage that "common men" trapped in dead-end lives feel. The pealing wallpaper and heat represent the rage stewing just under the surface, the flames are when Charlie's pent-up anger and resentments finally explode to the surface. Barton struggles through writing his first film, with deadlines about a wrestler. He seeks aid in the help of a famous writer's wife (Audrey) who he ends up sleeping with and he wakes up to her dead (slashed, bloody) body next to him. He finds out that Charlie is a serial killer who chops off people's heads from the police who question Barton after finishing his script. The studio hates the script and Charlie arrives at home to his apartment lit on fire by Charlie who kills the police investigators that are waiting for him with a shotgun.

The Hotel beings to burn and the wallpaper (which has been ripping off throughout the movie continues to rip away). Charlie then says my favorite line in the movie, as the apartment is burning to the ground: "If you need me, I'll be in my room." He then says he went to visit Barton's parents on the East coast where he is from and leaves Barton a gift in a box.

Barton leaves the apartment and walks on the beach where he sits down in front of a beautiful women which resembles exactly the picture of a woman on the beach that has rested on his wall of the hotel room that he had gazed at for release throughout his time spent there. This brings us to the last lines of the film between the woman and Barton:

Beauty: It's a beautiful day.
Barton: Huh?
Beauty: I said it's a beautiful day.
Barton: Yes. It is.
Beauty: What's in the box?
Barton: I don't know.
Beauty: Isn't it yours?
Barton: I don't know. You're very beautiful. Are you in pictures?
Beauty: Don't be silly.

The questions arise: what is in the box? what does the girl in the picture come to real life represent? and finally what does the wallpaper ripping off mean?

Here are some explanations I have dug up:

First of all this is like the briefcase in Pulp Fiction it is not meant to be known. I have always thought it was Barton's mind. He couldn't write before but once he got his mind back he was free to write away. Also at the end he finds out that Capital Pictures owns him and his mind so when the girl asks if that is his box he responds "I don't know" meaning he doesn't know if it belongs to him or to Capital Pictures.

Now this of course isn't supposed to be taking literally I know his mind isn't actually in the box but it is symbolic of it.

ALSO:

The suggestion seems to be that's it's Audrey's head. Yet, there's a very "Pulp Fiction" aspect to it as well where we're not really meant to know. And yet, more than in "Pulp Finction"- where the mystery remains much more sublime than any attempt at explantion- we seem invited to seek out an interpretation here to find one that is more symbolic than literal. Barton's "mind" or "the truth" are good ones- "mind" could also be interpreted as Barton's creativity or even his soul (much like those slightly tedious interpretations of Marcellus's briefcase- I reckon it works better here.) The only real clues we have are the size of the box and Mudnt's confession that he lied and that it doesn't really belong to him (ie. does that mean it's Audrey's head or something belonging to Barton?)

However, I think it's significant that Barton doesn't actually open the box- therefore doesn't actually release his mind/creatively/soul. The way I like to look at it is that it is that very mystery of not knowing what's in the box that finally releases his creativity (and so leaves the explanation unknown-like Pulp Fiction). The point that Barton also confesses that he doesn't know what's in the box- and therefore might mean that he doesn't know if he still owns his own creativity- is a good one, but it could work on this level too- ie. that he still doesn't know what's in the box and is- perhaps- still feeding of that mystery. Who knows? Do we really need to know? Sometimes unanswered questions are more inspirational than answered ones.


Personally I thought that what was in the box was the head of his parents who he went to visit, meaning that when you go to hell, you bring everyone you know down with you. What did you think?

Rotten Tomatoes give this move a 91% rating

Zoom In Analysis will DISAGREE with this rating and give it a 7.5 out of 10

Although there is a lot of ambiguity and the movie definitely pulls on the critics strings hitting all the right notes, it lacks audience appeal, but a great flick for those who love to interpret movies. If only judging it as a well written story with long lasting effect I would agree with RT, however when popping this movie into a wide appeal audience it won't be for everyone.

The masterpiece of the Coen brothers is a film that takes you, joining the poor hero (Turturro in his best performance), in a journey to hell or into the labyrinthine human  mind...You see, the questions that Coen are putting are not always answered...The viewer has to use his imagination and dig under the surface of this imaginative and  cerebral screenplay, one of the best ever written...A true masterpiece and one of the best movies of the 90s..

Don't even bother unless movies really are your thing, and especially not if you need to completely understand a film to enjoy it. It's a complex film but the imagery is just so powerful. The Coens obviously were influenced by the Shining, and they give The Hotel Earle a similar sense of horror about it. Turturro and Goodman are both fantastic.

It's certainly a movie that was interesting throughout, but by the end, I found myself not able to make total sense of it. The movie almost seemed dream-like toward the end, and I wasn't sure if that was the intent or not. There's definitely a lot to marinate on if you really break it down, and some of the themes are pretty clear, but after the initial viewing, I feel like I was left in the dark a little bit.

The ingenious dialogue and smart symbolic imagery is enough to distinguish Barton Fink as a Coen production. The humor is spot-on and on par with Raising Arizona and Burn After Reading. Turturro and Goodman are dynamic and radiate brilliance in every scene, as the film explores the mind of a Hollywood writer.

A movie that's sort of about Clifford Odets coming to Hollywood, but far more universal. It's almost about how one subverts one's ideals, if said ideals are merely vocal, and not acted upon. Apocalyptic fantasy about the nature of creation in a world on the brink of disaster, this is one that will be around for a while.
